Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

posts.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

Here we discuss microcontrollers, SBCs and microcontroller accessories, such as Atmel mega and tiny AVRs (Arduinos), PICs, ARM boards such as blue/black pill STM32, ESP8266/32s, RP2040, Raspberry Pi, and others.

For general electronics questions (power supplies, level shifting, motor driving, etc.) please ask /ohm/.

>where can I find verified quality microcontrollers and other electronic sensors or parts
digikey.com
mouser.com
arrow.com
newark.com

>but that's too expensive
aliexpress.com (many parts here are fake, particularly specific parts out of stock in the above sites)
lcsc.com

>I need a part that does X and Y, with Z specifications. How can I find it?
use digikey or mouser's parametric part search. Then purchase from one of the sellers listed above.

>how do I get started with microcontrollers, where should I start?
There is no defined starting point, grab a book and start reading or buy an arduino off ebay/amazon and start messing around. There are a plethora of examples online to get started.

>resources:
https://github.com/kitspace/awesome-electronics

Just finished fermenting a batch of bochet mead using honey from my bees. SG: 1.114 OG: 1020 I couldn't get the ec 1118 yeast to go any dryer than 1.020. I assume it's because the 13% alcohol kills them off? Tastes fine though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531384
Not him, my experience says 5 weeks to remove the worst volatile alcohols and make it drinkable, 3 months to really mature it (for almost everything). I drink like half of my stuff at 5 weeks and keep the rest indefinitely (until Christmas or birthday or whatever).

But it’s also (probably more) important to keep it in primary for long enough so that the yeasts will eat most of the less volatile heavy alcohols. Once it stops fermenting, give it 5-7 more days before going to secondary.

Letting it ferment dry helps a lot with clearing (low gravity drops the solids more easily) and you can backsweeten it after. Filtering is kind of difficult using a home set up (without sterile pumps and plate filters etc) and almost never really necessary imo

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2530969
Most important tip is what this anon said >>2530999
Best is to visit your supermarket or green grocer and check the "Old fruits and veggies for half price" section, because you really want soft bananas with black skin. If you don't have enough, put the black ones into the freezer and start collecting and ripening bananas over a couple of months.
Also note that the banana flavor is really soft and the wine won't taste like fresh banana juice. Better to start a small batch and see if the taste is too your liking. I like to combine banana with honey and make a banana mead, the flavors really complement each other.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2531375
You should get the fruit out after 1 to 1.5 weeks, raspberries can start to decay under absence of oxygen which creates sulfuric compounds which in turn spoils your wine. Just strain it while racking it into a second fermenter. Press the pulp, because the largest amount of your yeast will sit in there and you don't want to lose them. After that, you can only wait until fermentation is done.
Testing for sweetness while fermentation is still going will result in you throwing out your entire batch, because it will only taste of yeast and sourness. (Which is completely normal but might give the wrong impression to someone new to this hobby)
Let it ferment completely dry, until no airlock activity is visible, rack it and let it sit for 2 weeks to let it clear. Then you'll get the first impression of where the flavor of your wine is heading.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2531406
EC1118 should go to 18% but don't be fooled by the SG of 1.020, honey has some unfermentable sugars, it's really rare to get honey to ferment completely dry, even though you should end up around 1.008 at least. Are you really sure that fermentation is completely done?
Normally you should measure the SG, take note and measure again one week later to see if the gravity dropped further.

Also you have your terminology wrong.
OG (Original Gravity) is your starting point. FG (Final Gravity) is the value you end your fermentation with and with which you bottle your wine. SG (Specific Gravity) is just the "unit" of the gravity.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2533531
>tastes like crap
Blueberry and cherry is a really difficult combo, I can't really imagine those two working together properly.

I think most people don't really understand that fermentation fundamentally changes the taste of what you put into your fermentation vessel. Cherry wine will never taste like cherry juice and the wine will always taste shallower, that's in the nature of it and the exact reason why so many combine it with mead to give it a proper background or foundation.
Also, I can't stress it enough, buy yourself an acidity testing kit. I bet my arse that your acidity is nowhere near where it should be to allow the flavors to come to shine. For a simple fruit wine without any fancy extras I'd at least go for a 7.5g/l.
And in the end it will help to just let it rest for at least 2 months, it will taste like a whole different drink. But with your combo that's not as easy as it looks. Blueberry wines love aging, after a year they will develop a lovely complexity but you can't do that with cherries. Cherry wine will finish developing after 1-2 months and it won't get better than what you have at that time. After a year the flavor and aroma will start to decay and the cherry wine will slowly start to taste bland and hollow.

>>2534085
If you want a clean and fruity cherry flavor in your wine, you can do as you yourself suggested and simply mix your finished wine with cherry juice or you can add your cherries in secondary, that will leave a lot of the fresh fruitiness. I'd always suggest to use fresh, black cherries from summer-time and never use canned ones or the ones in mason jars.
Also depending on the cherries it might happen that your wine will get a slight hint of mouth wash. Some people think that cherry wine needs that mouth wash flavor, most people see it as a fault.

>>2533014
https://www.thehomebrewforum.co.uk/threads/how-to-make-turbo-cider.69059/

Turbo cider is very quick and simple. Bear in mind you CAN make it taste nice, but like any cider within the first 6 months it's likely to be pretty shit

tl;dr:
>get apple juice (ideally pressed apple juice but you can use juice from concentrate too)
>get yeast (in theory anything but in practice best to get a cider yeast or some kind of champagne/beer yeast)
>make a strong cup of black tea (to replace the tannin you'd get from the apple skins in normal cider)
>put them all in demijohn with airlock
>some guys put in more sugar (to increase alcohol %) or yeast nutrient but I've never done either
>just leave it for like 2-3 weeks, it should start bubbling due to fermentation
>that's basically it

posts.com: Why does everyone omit the +1 then calculating darlington gain?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533478
Fundamental theorem of engineering: approximation. There is no point in trying to get the exact figure when gain is varying by 400% due to manufacturing process variations. We're not doing science or math, it's perfectly fine to use methods that would make physicists or mathematicians cringe. No need to be autistic about analytical expressions - throw that shit in excel, copy over formulas from reference books/app notes, add some solver magic and then fudge values a bit more with simulator, real circuit will be off by a few percent anyways because of parasitics you didn't account for and model limitations. The trick is to understand when you can simplify without sacrificing required precision/predictive power.

Yes, it does make a new circuit, but one that is negligible. But you don't need to measure it to know that the voltage will be equal to the other side of the light bulb.
The infinite resistance is to make it possible to model the circuit. Otherwise you would need to consider the 3D resistance of all air, insulators, variances in the conductivity of the wires, imperfections in the supply voltages, electromagnetic noise coming from space, your local radio station blasting noise into your circuit, your neighbor's bluetooth sending noise into the system, etc. Just use a model that gets the job done well enough. The little thing's won't matter in almost every case

posts.com:
Welcome to the woodworking general, here we discuss the working of wood and the tools and techniques of working wood. So far we tend to be mostly hand tool folk with a slant towards cabinetry and carving but all are welcome and we have some capable power tool folk amount our ranks. General carpentry question such as framing/decking/general construction seems to get a better response in the /qtddtot/ or /sqt/.

>essential /wwg/ books
Tage Frid Teaches Woodworking, gives you everything you need and shows you how to do it multiple ways from hand tools to power tools and gives you the knowledge to determine which is best, and then he teaches you how to apply what you learned. The PDF of the second book can be found in the usual places, but the other two are MIA.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561588261

Christopher Schwarz tells you everything you need to know about planes and saws and their use
Handplane Essentials
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440332983
Handsaw Essentials
Best to find this one in PDF from the usual sources, out of print and pricey!

Chris Pye wrote the book on carving and keeps on writing them.
https://www.chrispye-woodcarving.com/

The eastern tradtion, Japanese Woodworking Tools: Their Tradition, Spirit and Use by Toshio Odate
https://www.amazon.com/dp/0941936465

Leonard Lee The Complete Guide to Sharpeninig, how to sharpen most everything.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561581259

Bob Flexner - Finishing 101, covers the common stuff, his other books cover the uncommon and go into more depth
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440308454/

Illustrated Cabinet Making by Bill Hylton, learn to design furniture that won't fall apart
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1565233697/

>essential /wwg/ tv
https://www.pbs.org/show/woodwrights-shop/
https://www.newyankee.com/

previous thread >>2514390

Beginner's guide to tools https://www.thecrucible.org/guides/woodworking/

Show us your mallet!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532202
>toxic sawdust and septic splinters
Some woods present more danger than others but fwiw all wood dust can be dangerous to aspirated in the kinds of concentrations seen in woodworking, and almost any plant material injected subcutaneous will decompose and fester.
Be safe and all that, just saying that the precautions and related labels attached to working with certain wood species don't necessarily apply to using items made from them, even for eating off of.
Oak splinters are also intensely painful compared to other woods and fester quickly, but oak is used all the time for aging and storing food.
Almost any wood is a potential allergen/ irritant and very few trees are directly toxic...weed out the ones that aren't used for commercial lumber like oleander and the list of truly poisonous lumber sources is tiny

https://www.wood-database.com/wood-articles/wood-allergies-and-toxicity/

That said any commercially made wood product from China carries thecrisk of having been treated with or exposed to God knows what.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532243
I don't know how much you already have and know how to do, but I can recommend looking through Rex Krueger's "Woodwork for humans" video series on youtube, especially if you're starting out with nothing.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLR_8ISkKkV7ky1wbbBUkE3-kwH6LRRWY1
Theres enough in there to start a handtool workshop with a japanese saw, a bit-brace with auger bits, a knife, a clamp, and some measuring and marking tools, but you gotta make your own watch-order cause the whole thing is a bit too disjointed to be a clear starter guide. I'd suggest going Japanese sawhorses, Chopping-block workbench, make a mallet with 3 tools, then pick some of the simple projects like milking stool or tool tote to get started. Then you can look into making a proper workbench and take on bigger projects once you have a bit of experience.
Alternative, his book "Everyday Woodworking - A beginner's guide to woodcraft with 12 hand tools" is also a good intro, it is basically the same as the videos but ordered and condensed.

You'll probably eventually want to advance to powertools, especially if you're gonna be building something large like a cabin. But getting started with handtools is a great way to learn, and as it says in the book;
>"Once you understand wood and know the basic techniques, you can still buy those machines. They're not going anywhere."

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2532243
Eventually you will need a decent bench.

3 essentials:
Correct height for you
Stable
Perfectly flat surface.

No shame in buying one if you want, HF has a hardwood one that is quite reasonably priced and last I looked, good quality for the cost.
If you choose to make one, consider using MDF for the top.

I don't really like MDF, but it is dimensionally stable and perfectly flat.

Cheap, too. Some people make it so they can replace the top piece of MDF every year or so when they bang up the surface.

I would make it a modest size so that if and when you build a fancier one later, you don't need to get rid of it.


https://www.finewoodworking.com/2013/03/13/a-basic-bench-thats-quick-to-make

https://www.woodchoppintime.com/beginners-woodworking-bench/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533020
With linseed oil you traditionally apply one coat per day for a week, one coat per week for a month, one coat per month for a year and one coat per year for the rest of your life. It's a drying oil so you don't seal it. If you want it to seal the traditional solution is danish oil, which used to be 1/3rd boiled linseed oil, 1/3rd turpentine and 1/3rd varnish but can apparently be anything now.

>>2533056
Mahagony has a natural anti-rot resistance, as does teak. That's why it's use for fine furniture and boats. For Mahogany it's the tight grain, for teak it's the grain and a high level of oils and silica in the wood. There are species that are hard woods that are durable and resist rot naturally. Cedar is rot resistant, but it's too soft for furniture or boats.

Drying oil is bad for a table surface, there's too much wear. Poly is fine if it's not something formal, like if you game a lot, and use the desk every day.

I helped my dad finish an oak kitchen table when I was a kid, and put mulitple coats of poly on it, sanding between each one. 30 years later, it's still looks good.

Finish can be aesthic, or function. Any surface you're going to use daily, shellac or poly. Tung oil looks great, but doesn't wear as well. And, will be more sensitive to things like water rings, scratches, etc. It's a nice finish, for sure, but you'll be redoing it a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2533599
>American specialty glues
Look at what wood glues are available, look for one that is a aliphatic resin emulsion, this is what Titebond is and it is a common wood glue around the world.
>>2533659
>Also, Titebond isn't better than generic PVA
Original Titebond is an aliphatic resin emulsion and much better than PVAs for wood, exhibits far less creep and has enough flexibility to hold up to seasonal wood movement. PVA is fine if that is all you have (Titebond II or III is PVA) but aliphatic resin emulsions are far better than polyvinyl acetates for wood.

posts.name: Anonymous

I was just talking about strength, where the determining factor invariably ends up being the wood itself because all the glues are stronger anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533684
>where the determining factor invariably ends up being the wood itself because all the glues are stronger anyway.
PVA is not really the equal of Titebond here either, its brittleness is a massive drawback and PVA joints can be cleanly separated with a well directed mallet blow, the glue will just shatter at the joint. This and the creep are the primary reason for aliphatic resin emulsion based glues to become the standard wood glue. Even hide glues do better than PVA thanks to their far greater flexibility. Hide glues have a similar weakness to shock as PVAs but only release when shear forces are in the mix, drawback is poor moisture resistance which PVA is one of the best for. The saving grace for hide glues is high heat resistance and repairability better than any other common glue.

tbc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533713
cont.

The tests for glue strength commonly seen on youtube and the like are terrible and do not really represent how most joints fail over time. These supposed tests put the force primarily on the wood and not on the joint leaving the physical properties of the wood the primary determiner of strength, really they demonstrate the peel strength and resistance to splitting of the wood more than anything. Below is relative to the glues listed, for example; ARE is not actually good on water resistance but it is better than hide in that regard.

Aliphatic Resin Emulsion
Poor - gap filling, heat resistance, repairability, and reversibility
Good - water and creep resistance
Great - Shock resistance

Polyvinyl Acetate/PVA
Poor - shock, gap filling, flexibility, creep, heat, and repairability
Good - reverseability
Great - water resistance

Hide
Poor - water resistance and gap filling
Good - shock resistance but only if that force is not perpendicular to the joint.
Great - flexibility, creep, heat, repairability and reversibility

Polyurethane/PU
Poor - Heat, reversibility and probably repairability
Good - gap filling
Great - shock water and creep resistance

Epoxy
Poor - reversibility, repairability and heat resistance
Good - gap filling, this can be great with the addition of fillers at the cost of sacrificing other things
Great - shock, water, creep

With repairability I referring to how well it can repaired after the glue fails, as in after 40 years of wood movement has sheared the wood fibers from the glue and it just separates. PVA and ARE do not stick to themselves so the old glue must be removed before regluing or a glue which will stick to them must be used but that is generally a short lived repair. Hide glue and epoxy are the only common glues which happily stick to themselves, PU might but I do not know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533721
> Hide glue and epoxy are the only common glues which happily stick to themselves, PU might but I do not know
PU glue doesn’t stick wel to dried PU glue at all. It can be repaired with CA glue fairly well though.

Epoxy does btw - it will readily stick to itself and the new bond will be about as strong as the original one. But epoxy and PU both have additional drawbacks in handling (you need gloves) where PVA is non toxic

I would recommend either installing the preamp or a new preamp properly so it looks good or turning it into a sound port with or without removable cover. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533922
>a rectangular sound port?
Sure, the sound waves don't care much about the shape. There are probably more guitars with rectangular sound ports than oval or round out there, it is a common solution to no longer needed electronics. Rectangular also has the advantage of being easy to bind so it does not look like a hole just carved into the guitar without care. Binding is not a must for you since you say it has laminated sides but it will help keep the finish from getting chipped around the opening if you do add it.
>coping saw
Threading that through the sound hole will not be fun and you will have a short and awkward stroke. I would probably just whittle it away with a knife if I had nothing more suited to the task, slow but it will leave a good edge as long as you take it slow and don't try and take too large of a bite. Rasp or even a round bastard file will do as well, rasp will splinter things out bad on the inside, bastard will do better here but be slower. All of these would not hurt from having some tape applied to the inside, green painters masking tape will do, helps reduce the splintering. If you go the coping saw route make sure it cuts on the push and not the pull or it will leave things a mess on the outside, splintering and chipped finish.
>>2533932
It takes months, dries quicker in the winter assuming you are somewhere that winter means the heat is on, dry air and all that. I just give such things a daily coat for the first week or so, as much as the wood will absorb, and then put it to use, giving it a fresh coat after each washing (after it has dried from that washing). As long as the wood is good and saturated with the oil then food will not soak in much and what does will wash out. Just don't leave it in that pot of simmering marinara unless you want to turn it red. If you really want to make sure it does not get stained then give it a good coat of oil before use as well for that first month or so.

Layout is 90% of the job, cutting the joint is simply cutting to the line. Don't listen to the pocket hole crowd, the mortise and tenon is the most important joint in wood working and good to learn early. Learn to do tenons on the table saw and by hand with saw and chisel, learn to both chop and drill and square your mortises. And invest in layout tool, trysquare, dividers, mortise gauge, marking gauge, cutting gauge, etc, the layout tools are often left off of essential tool lists but are rather important.

Dedicated pore fillers are the common way, so or like wood putty but only capable of filling tiny holes. Sandpaper and BLO/Tung is another way, just apply the thinned oil with wet dry sandpaper, repeat until finished. This is a fairly tricky technique to get down since you need to learn how thin to mix the oil and how fine the dust needs to be to get a proper mix of oil and dust in the pores.
>>2534367
I don't think you can get it all out, I thought I had it all out and then one day the light hit it just right and after that I never could not see it. I do not think enough oxygen makes it under the finish for it to be an issue, maybe after a century. I would highly recommend filling the pores before sanding the brass flush. A few coats of thin shellac might be enough in a wood like walnut, do the shellac the day before sanding flush, wipe down with alcohol to remove the shellac on the surface along with the brass dust. Any finish can over shellac so need to worry and all that will remain is the stuff beneath the surface. I still would just fill the pores.

You could reduce the thickness and the width of the tenon of that side member so that it won't weaken that corner so much. Alternatively you could increase its width, which would increase the distance between the tenons for a similar effect. Probably more important is to just reduce the thickness. You'll get a pretty good amount of strength by virtue of glueing the side to the bottom so that side member's tenon is almost superfluous.

posts.com: What does this do that a table saw can’t?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534671

In a technical sense, not much. A tablesaw is essentially capable of anything a chop saw like that is and will likely be more accurate. A sliding miter would be more useful than a chop saw like that, though.

But as a complimentary tool, it's nice to have, it's more portable, and most people aren't going to cut compound angles on a table saw. I don't think there is much you can't do with a tablesaw compared to that but they are more convenient for a lot of tasks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534671
nothing, but for anything to do with construction, it does it 90% faster with repeatable accuracy. good luck cutting 300 2x4x10's and 100 2x6x12's to length with a tablesaw before lunch break

posts.name: Anonymous

Tripped the sawstop twice in our shop, once on mirror-backed acrylic- not too different from your situation- and once on a piece of regular old plywood that was painted on one side.

Doug would of course claim that that pic just shows how needlessly complicated a typical bermuda rigged boat is and that junks are superior on that count alone but a) that's not a typical bermuda rig even for something intended for singlehanding and doesn't *need* that many lines led aft...and b) junk running rigging isn't necessarily simple, especially when set up for singlehanded operation.
Picrel is the boat of the guy who did more to advance singlehanded offshore sailing and junk rig adaptation to modern/western hull forms than anyone, just as an example of what a proper setup looks like.
He was a legendary yachtsman and pioneer in offshore sailing techology and junk rigging who proved his ideas with multiple blue water passages, I doubt that Doug would even recognize his name if he heard it.
Also worth noting that after that boat was proven seaworthy and safe in a number of Atlantic crossings, it sank on an Atlantic crossing-

"Jester competed in the first OSTAR Transatlantic race in 1960, which was won by Sir Francis Chichester in Gypsy Moth II . Jester came second. She competed in every single subsequent OSTAR, but in 1989 was seriously damaged under sail and lost."
http://www.collars.co.uk/uk_galaxy/info/1/masts_and_spars/6/the_famous_modified_folkboat_jester

>mizzen
Why even have a mizzen mast?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531128
Split rigs in general allow smaller, easier to handle sails for
any given sail area, which is why they're popular for cruising boats.
Two masted schooners tend to be less naturally balanced (lots of power generated way aft) and harder to control and three masted versions can help balance the sail area out.
Marconi ketches and yawls can be made better balanced than a sloop with a mizzen and allow more sail combinations like jib and mizzen for low power in high winds or a adding mizzen staysail for more power and in light winds.
They can also allow sail/ rig configurations that take advantage of certain loopholes in racing rules, and some yawls are basically just sloops with a mizzen added for some advantage, while ketches are usually designed and masts positioned to use all the masts in normal conditions and may not sail or bslance well without the mizzen.
It's even possible to use the mizzen sheet and a bungee cord to make a ketch or yawl self steer.
In Seekers case much of this will not apply because the mizzen is pretty small and that pilothouse and bulwarks is a massive amount of windage.

posts.com:
>>2525741
Generally you can look at the pH.
Mild Akalines for organic stuff like food stains and microbes.
Mild Acids for inorganic stuff like limescale, rust, all the oxides. But you need to rinse/neutralize those surfaces after because microbes thrive in mildly acidic environments.
Strong Akalines aka Bleach kinda works on both.
Strong Acids are too destructive for regular household cleaning, imo.

The fancy OTS cleaners have surfactants mixed in that makes scrubbing far easier so don't dismiss them completely.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2526545
Yes. Jacks aren’t made to hold cars up. They’re made to lift cars and then you use the jack stands to actually hold the car. Any jack is going to slowly lose pressure and drop, and a well used jack is going to drop faster. The Chinese steel teeth on a $30 pair of jack stands are far more reliable than the Chinese rubber seals inside the jack.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2526554
Layer it bra. Long johns on real cold days, decent pants, good socks, and then your choice of undershirt, a hoodie or fleece (the hoodie hoods are always more comfy than big jackets), and then whatever jacket that isn’t too puffy and thick.

You gotta strike that balance right before you start to sweat. 25F with the sun and manual labor, you will be good in the hoodie. 0F with wind and clouds just standing around, get your top layer jacket. Something about shells, the swooshy sounding jackets like windbreakers that don’t suck up water, those are good for top layers.

Look for gloves with thinsulate if that’s still around. I used to love these mittens where the 4 finger cover flips up and you get those hobo looking gloves and can use your fingertips.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:

>>2526559

Is there a quick and reversible way to block a sewer pipe? (other than Mexican food).

The reason I ask is that my house has a really funky and not-code sewer drain, with a total of four sewage reflux gullies that are too high to do anything. I don't want to go to the expense of doing the right thing and installing a sewage reflux valve, but I do get very nervous about the sewer main blocking up and my house being the first one to fill with shit.
I've been putting it off since I bought the house, but I had a bit of a shock last night when a small clog inside one of those gullies made my shower backflow with sewage when I tried to drain some water from my pool.

So my idea is I make (or buy?) some kind of device to manually block off my entire sewer line as close to the mains as possible, just in the situation where I do suddenly have sewage rushing into my house.
I'm thinking a similar concept to pic rel, but on some sort of stick or flexible hose which I can jam down the closest point to the mains (probably one of those gullies) and then completely seal off the sewer pipe.
Does such a thing exist, or is there a way to make it? And is it a terrible idea?
My current idea is some kind of inflatable ball on a hose, where I jam the ball down the pipe and then use compressed air (probably from a CO2 cartridge) to fill it up. When the mains blockage is cleared, I would just release the pressure and pull the ball back out.

>tl;dr how do I make an inflatable dildo for my sewer drain?

posts.com:
>>2525741
Like >>2526116 said, you can often look at the pH as one way. Alcohol, a soapy detergent, and a mild acid can cover 99% of your cleaning needs if you understand what type of mess you're dealing with. >>2527241
the time of picking up good deals on vintage tools ended when everyone had access to the internet in their pocket
if you're just getting into the hobby, buy cheap crap from harbor freight little by little. as you work, you'll begin to get an idea of what tools are okay when they're cheap, and which ones you need better versions of.
if it breaks, it doesn't matter because it's cheap, and then you can replace it with something that will better suit your needs of higher quality.
get some projects done before you fully commit or else you'll end up with a garage full of tools that you don't use because it turns out you don't really like woodworking

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527705
Different purposes Anon. Trigger clamps are useful for joining boards so you use many of them over the entire length and don’t put them extremely tight. F clamps are more useful for putting a lot of pressure on a few points. If you put a few f clamps very tight while glue laminating the wood will warp around eg knots and the result will be less flat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529033
the two black wires on the right are connected inside the switch. the black wire on the left is connected to the other two when the switch is closed. the ground is the bare twisted wires back in the box.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529048
I figured, it confused me when I pulled it out, but now it makes sense. it's just an ungrounded switch and there are other outlets on this circuit, so one of the wires on the right is hot and the other one the right continues to the other outlets, and the left is the neutral, right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529052
>so one of the wires on the right is hot and the other one the right continues to the other outlets, and the left is the neutral, right.

yes. this is known as a "circuit tripper" switch because it is a convenient way to trip the breaker without having to go to the panel.

I turned the breaker back on and used my voltage pen to find the hot one.

>>2529084

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529102
Ground on a switch doesnt really do anything because the load isnt in the switch but in the lamp, and the switch is itself a breaker for the flow of current.

Im not a burger so things may be different in the EU, but we never ground switches. Only at best the metal parts of the lamp itself. Its also normal to just have both hot/phase/plus cables in the same colour. With a switch you can usually tell which is which because one goes upward toward the lamp. Code also says supplying wire needs to be mounted on the bottom side of the switch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529873
This is bad juju anon. The point of a circuit breaker is to isolate the circuit line conductor.
Doesnt matter what protection, how little current it leaks, how safe it is, do not hide something weird and unexpected in mains wiring.
Now if this is all just on the bench and connected to your house by a plug or something then ok maybe that's different, but it will still leak current and perhaps be very dangerous.
It also wont necessarily work at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Can anyone recommend a good stud finder?

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2532606
They all kind of suck. Look at the reviews, the <$15 Zircon to the $50+ Franklins are all the same… inconsistent.

The basic magnetic ones that find the screws in the drywall are the most reliable. The more expensive electronic stud finders all have extra shit like a laser to mark the stud or the ability to find wires behind the drywall, but they all use the same exact system to search for the studs and it’s always like 60% accurate no matter on the model. I recently went through thie when I bought a Zircon with some fancy features thinking it would be better than my old 10-15 year old guy, and it’s just as reliable as the cheaper Zircon that was dying and the really cheap Walmart B&D that had batteries explode inside.

So get the magnet, or get an electronic one, but don’t expect the $70 electronic one to locate studs any better than the $12 electronic one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532608
Thanks for the tips. I'll just go for the $20 Zircon then.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2532620
Yea honestly just find a spot where you get a good, clean, consistent hit with the stud finder, try to mark the center, and measure from that one stud.

I think that blue Zircon was still like $30, and I would’ve gone with the Franklin if they were any more consistent but they’re not. The blue one has the laser to mark the middle of the stud, it’s a nice feature but it only works half the time just like all the other stud finders, and it’s easy enough to find the center with the cheaper ones when they actually locate a stuf. The electricity sensing things are goofy, I would never rely on them for safety, just see if you have any outlets or switches in line with where you’re trying to drill.

Read the reviews of all the Home Depot and Lowe’s studfinders besides the magnet ones and they’re all the same, like 3.5 stars average. I don’t know why nobody can make a good one.

posts.com:
This a story. I live in a trailer. My kitchen sink is clogged. It fills up with water almost instantly as soon as you turn the knobs. I assumed that somewhere between the sink and the grinder, there was a clog. That's reasonable? I tried a drain snake but it was only 20 feet long so I hired a plumber.

He came over with a 100 foot drain snake. He put it down my drain and it looked like the water ran through. Then it filled right back up. So he ran it again. And it filled right back up. He ran his drain snake 8 times and each time he pulled it out, it looked like the pipe was draining (though I do understand that the snake itself was simply displacing the water into the bucket under the out).

After he had done this five times he became baffled and began asking me to go out to the grinder and look inside. I did. The drain head was all the way into the grinder.

None of the other drains that all empty into the same pipe and all flow into the grinder are clogged. My toilet runs fine. I shower. I wash my hands and brush my teeth daily. My washing machine does not flood the narrow hallway.


After two hours he left, completely unsure why my kitchen sink does not drain; His snake unclogs many restaurants and retail stores with far higher usage than my sink. Eventually he left, but did not charge me for his time and effort. He just did not understand it.

I don't understand it.


Can you determine WHY my kitchen sink does not drain is every thing else is fine and he even pushed it all the way through to the other side? I have included a simplified version of my trailer, plumber and pipe setup to, I hope, convey what is wrong and help SOMEBODY tell me how it can still be clogged.

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533551
there is no such thing. many are outdated af, and a lot of options are missing hidden or moved. one of the shitty things about fusion360.

and there is nothing on the basic work loop:
1. start a sketch pick a plane
2. <draw 2d in the sketch tool on that plane>
3. "finish sketch" to exit the 2d plane tool
4. select sketch elements to extrude. use q or e key (they are slightly different)
5. change parameters for extrusion and type (join cut new obj) which are autoselected.
6. OK and you have a solid shape.
7. sketch will autohide. if you need additional operations use the eye under sketches.
repeat from 1.

working with new object even when you want a cut allows more functions.

you have to choose copy under the move option before moving, otherwise the option gets grayed out.

try to delay boolean operations until everything else is done. ditto with chamfers and filets, doing them early can cause errors and problems with future manipulation.

you can go back in the timeline and do things like add to a sketch or change the parameters of an extrude. this often requires redoing one or more subsequent operations.

after an object exists 'q' will stretch or reduce previous selections as a new step. 'e' will use the profile for a new extrude. operating on faces like this will have slightly different dialog choices between the two.

HTH fusion360 is powerful but pretty fucking convoluted.

posts.com:
I just want to say how immensely disappointed in SLA printing I am.
If you are thinking about getting into it and have experience with FDM printing, prepare to be shocked. The only similarities that these two processes share is that they both use a slicer and the printers make things. The slicers that are available are extremely limited, unless you want to pay money for them. This is completely against the open source idea. Well you can use Pr*saSlicer if you want but unless you have one of their SLA printers, you are going to need to convert it into the format your printer uses. You know why? Because each manufacturer has their own bullshit proprietary format. So you have to use a program called UV Tools to convert it to the right format.
With my printer (chinkshit especial) connecting the printer via USB does nothing.mi either have to use WiFi, a USB stick, or Cr*ality's cloud app. No thanks for that.
The software is limited and it's bullshit. But you know what else is closed source? The fucking hardware. Which means you aren't going to do anything like put custom firmware on your machine. Some of them maybe I guess but it's nothing like putting Klipper on a FDM printer. Not that Klipper would help anyways because the process is so different.
I've read some stuff about people working on a open source SLA printer. I long for the day. This proprietary shit pisses me off so bad and it goes against everything the RepRap movement stands for. Fuck Ch*tu, Pr*sa, Fuck El*goo, and especially, fuck Cr*ality.

>>2534011

Using the aux level option

Set the z offset at center using the provided piece of paper as a gauge

Then go to the corners, also using the paper as a gauge, but this time use the knobs on the bed to level that spot.

After this is done you run the auto level once.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533975
>Question 1: what could cause these these lines in the layers?
Could be overextrusion. Have you calculated your esteps for your extruder? If not, you need to do so.
>>2533978
>What causes these dots?
Probably overextrusion or maybe flow. It's the same problem as the other question. Your printer is pushing too much plastic out.
>>2533980
>How come I have these ripples in the print?
Probably ghosting. Hard to explain but basically when your printer moves it vibrates and the vibrations get transferred to your print. You could try printing slower, you could get some dampeners for your steppers. Preferably you would get your printer set up on Klipper and then go through the testing. You can also adjust your acceleration if you don't change the firmware. It could be mechanical though so check every screw on your frame and tighten your belts. Get a carpenter's square and make sure you frame is PERFECTLY square (if you haven't already).
>>2533982
>all arches are crappy at the top
Might be related to overextrusion. If you set the slicing right, your printer will slow down on overhangs/bridges like that.

If I was you, I would go through this guide to get everything set up: https://teachingtechyt.github.io/calibration.html . Its quite involved but really important to do, especially on an Ender 3. Watch the guy's video and then go through the process. After you can print his test print successfully, try the Benchy again. If you follow his calibration guide, your printer will print great.
What layer height are you using? It's not obvious but your layer height needs to be divisible by 0.04 which is the size of a single step. There is also a relationship between the diameter of your nozzle and the layer height. Which slicer are you using?

They're rather thoroughly designed for cheapness, in both senses. >Well when you put it like that it does seem like the SL1 is the superior choice.
In a lot of ways, it is. Besides the ones mentioned above, the tilting bed stirs the resin at each layer, making things like settle-prone pigments and glitter go a lot nicer. It's also really fast. It's definitely more of a "prosumer" or small business machine than Prusa's current FDM printers. Are those features worth a $2000 price to you?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534539
Have you tried removing the nozzle and pushed a bowden tube through to push out any gunk?
And/or cold pulling?
>pull filament back
>remove pneumatic connector at the nozzle to reveal the top of the heat sink
>with nozzle at printing temp, push some filament in until oozing occurs at the nozzle
>dial temperature down to 60°C
>gently apply pressure while temp drops
>when temp hits 60°C, dial it back up to printing temp
>switch to gently pulling on the filament
>filament should pull free in the shape of the interior of the nozzle and heat block, along with any gunk that was in there, as it approaches printing temp

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2534701
>what makes pla+ harder to work with
Probably from being a catchall category for anything various manufacturers want to add to PLA, leading to different optimal printing parameters. With PLA, you can get a generic setting that probably works decently for most PLA, but with PLA+, good settings for one might cause a print failure for another. And PLA is kind of the gold standard for easy printability, so any changes are downhill from there.

What's the adhesion like compared to ABS? Would an all-metal hot-end be recommended?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534777
240-260, I print asa at 250c/110c. You don't need all metal. It doesn't really like to stick to anything other than glass I've found. If you enclose your printer it doesn't warp. I print it on a bog standard ender 6 with top enclosure. Picrel is with vs without top enclosure. It's incredibly accurate stuff and tougher than aluminum. All metal hotends will clog up where ptfe ends don't. Your best bet is getting a ruby nozzle and an enclosure before anything else. Once you get it to print, cool inside the enclosure. You might want to build it out of wood to trap the heat. Print slow. 50mm/s max. Anyone who says otherwise is trolling you. You want to maximize ambient temperatures for asa for as long as possible. I put in my gcode to slowly cool the bed by 5c every 15 minutes. Just set it and once you get that first layer, leave it the fuck alone. Go play wow, go to bed, go fuck your so. It's best left alone until it's cool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534796
>>2534799
To expedite this, the offered sale price of a thing (anything) is what the seller thinks they can get for it. The cost to procure the item in question is entirely unrelated to this calculus, so put that out of your mind for now. Whether the offered price turns into a sale depends on whether anyone wants to buy the thing at that price, which depends on how much people want the thing (now how much it costs to procure the thing). The interplay of this over multiple sales determines a "market price", for the item in question. If the seller is a small fish in the market, there is little they can do about this price, but big fish can trade off to some degree between high prices with lower sales numbers and lower prices with higher sales numbers. Where procurement cost comes in is that procurement cost vs. market price is what determines whether the seller stays in the market or not. If the profit margin is nonexistent or too small to justify the endeavor, the seller stops selling.

Regarding the question of whether Prusas are overpriced, Prusa Research sells enough of them at current prices that they have been continually upscaling their manufacturing capacity, and things are still back-ordered extensively. Economically, this indicates that they are under-priced, but presumably they want to maintain customer loyalty by not jacking prices up, and that this is more valuable long-term.

>>2534844
No moving motors means that the moving gantry can be lighter than on a cartesian. The fastest current printers are small core XY ones where belt and other resonance is manageable. At larger scales, cartesian becomes more favorable. At even larger scales (e.g. industrial CNC machines) rigid drive mechanisms become favored over belts despite the even larger moving mass.

>>2534856
On this note I want to share a few things I found:
All metal hotends are fucking trash. All these higher end filaments print looking like shit compared to the likes of petg and pla.
Linear rails should be a requirement on all 3d printers.
Enclosures help a LOT.
When printing PETG and PLA, a heated bed might not always be your best bet, so turn it off after the first layer prints, and print with a brim. It will print cleaner as the cooling fan pulls less hot air in from the bed.
Printing slower can solve just about any issues. Going over 80mm/s offers nothing but headaches. You can't print faster than physics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531818
I'd say your thought is on the right track, but this ain't it chief.
Gravity forcing the heavier cold air rushing out and get replaced with room-temp air that then needs to be cooled when opening and closing a side-operated door, and the seal having to fight the same cold air even when closed, should in theory make normal side-operated fridges much less energy efficient than top-operated ones, especially with frequent use. This assuming everything else about the two units being equal, indeed we see this in freezers where top-operated 'chest' freezers are common and consistently more energy efficient than their side-operated counterparts.

But things aren't always equal, and electric coolers have problems. First the simple inconvenience factor from having to stack things on top of each other instead of putting them on a shelf. Then theres that coolers have very very varying build quality, even more so than mini fridges which are already a mixed bag compared to standard fridges, chances of getting one with shit insulation is high. Coolers also generally have weaker compressors cause they're made for portability (and some have peltiers which are even worse), so on a hot day (or just a normal day if you live somewhere fairly warm) you might not be able to get down to fridge temps.
If you want anything half-decent, you're going to be spending at least $300 for a 45L/48 quarts cooler, maybe $400, and best case scenario the energy savings will make it break-even in 10 years, provided it doesn't shit itself at the 5 year mark.

You're probably better off spraypainting your existing fridge grey and not opening it as often.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534401
>How do I put the pattern on the fabric?
I use chalk. Tailors chalk is worth buying, and its dirt cheap.

>Would it be fine to draw an outline then cut pieces as I need to?
I am not aware of any laws that would violate.

>How would I sew the ends of the fabric so that they don't get frayed and torn?
Usually you use a hem. Your pattern will usually account for this

Some general advice:
Pick a small project to practice on, and use a dirt cheap material like an old bed sheet.

Iron your raw material, iron again after cutting out the pieces, and iron your seams/hems before sewing. Goes a long way to making your stitches look right.

Understand that just because you have a pattern, it doesn't mean that it will just magically fit you. You still have to tailor many garments. For this reason, I really recommend using a seam ripper and taking apart an old shirt that first you well, and make your own pattern from that. It's a good practice project too. There's tons of youtube tutorials on patterning, just don't forget your seam allowances.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534401
Typically patterns come on tissue paper that you're expected to either cut out and pin to your fabric before cutting, or use a pattern wheel (either the spikey one the dashed one plus carbon paper) to transfer to the fabric. There is a facebook group that has a bunch of info on using cheap projectors mounted above a cutting table to bypass that completely; I recommend that shit highly if you get into it, it's been great to just weigh fabric down, project, and go around it with a rotary cutter (you should use a cutting mat and rotary cutter even if you don't do a projector).

Go to a thrift shop and buy a few 100% cotton sheets / duvets and use them as fabric to make yourself some pillow cases and pajama pants and then go from there.

Your machine will have a zig zag stitch or an overlock stitch that you can use with or instead of various seam finishing techniques to prevent fraying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
there's a long line on each pattern piece with an arrow at one or both ends of it that's labeled "grainline" or similar. align the pattern pieces so that the grainline runs parallel to the selvage (i.e. the edges that don't fray) of the fabric. if you're doing each piece one at a time on a single layer of fabric, don't forget to flip the paper over before doing the second cut so you end up with mirrored pieces.
>How would I sew the ends of the fabric so that they don't get frayed and torn?
"edge finishing" and "seam finishing" are the search terms you want. what's appropriate depends on what you're making. french seams are efficient and tidy, look that one up.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2530706
What >>2530708 said r.e. sound booth. You're fighting an uphill battle against physics here. Easiest way to deal with it is management i.e. don't be loud at night, dumbass.

However if you really want to try some sort of engineering solution, I'll give you a test you can run which is similar to what we do when testing acoustically rated walls. First, play some 'pink noise' through your loudspeakers nice and loud. Go to the other room and listen - if you hear mainly a hissing sound, find the direction it's coming from and look around there for gaps and cracks between the loudspeaker and the receiving room. If it's a lower rumbling noise you hear, then the issue is mass so there's not much you can do without building a new or additional partition.

You could add some absorption inside your room, if so then get products which are min 25mm thick (so it will work better with lower end of human voice frequencies). Tack it to the wall at head height if you aren't covering the entire wall. This might help a little with reducing noise buildup in the room (and the amount of noise then leaking out), but I doubt it would completely solve your issue.

Easy but limited effect:
Put down rugs/carpeting
Hang heavy curtains around your walls
Put soft things around the room (I dunno, fabric couch? plushies?)

More investment:
Cover the walls and ceiling in foam panels or cardboard (cheaper but more accessible)
Put down a snap-together floor on top of your current one, and put one more layer of underlay in than normal

Renovation-tier:
Open the top of each wall and fill with noise-rated insulation
Go into the attic and replace with noise-rated insulation
Tear up the floors and use better construction with heavier or sound-rated materials, or install a false-ceiling in the room below

Drum bum reporting in. Cork is an excellent and cheap soundproofing material. If you can open your walls you can insert sheets of cork which will soundproof but also insulate. Without renovation it will be extremely hard to get the actual soundproofing you desire
>no renovation
Get a large corkboard for behind your gamer station (with the bonus of you can use it for real life too)
Get large and thick tapestries and hang them on your walls. You can hang sheets of cork on your wall underneath the tapestries. You could probably get each wall for $50-100 per wall using this strategy and you would see massive benefit even from making just an L along two adjacent walls.
Put anything and everything you can on the walls in the hallway, especially a tapestry if you can. If you have any furniture you can put in the hallway do it
Rugs for your room and hallway if uncarpeted
Get a cheap air filter for your home, the plug in kind. Put it in the hallway between rooms and run it at night as a white noise insulator (bonus: it purifies your air)
Get your sister a personal air fan to use at night and explain how American/British/French women love to fan themselves at night (use whichever you think is most impressive to your sister). The white noise close to her will be even better than an air filter or fan in the hallway.
Reposition the furniture of your room to your advantage. Move your gamer station to the furthest corner of your room and try to place your bed and bookshelves/tables/dresser/furniture between your gamer station and the rest of your home. Face your gamerstation so you aren't speaking towards family member rooms

Hang blankets across your walls and doors

>>2523144
>Anybody here make their own cigarettes? Is its easy?
Yeah, it's easy to use the tube stuffing type machines if you don't want to hand roll them.
It's probably faster to use the stuffing machine too. I used the "topomatic" type machine.
>Cheaper then manufactured ones?
It's way way fucking cheaper. Do the math; you can get a pound of decent tobacco for like 15$ and tubes to go with it for another 5$ and make about 20 packs of cigarettes.
It'll probably average you around a dollar per pack or less.

One problem with doing this though is that the cigarettes won't be exactly like your favorite store brand. They won't taste exactly the same because cigarette manufacturers use a proprietary blend of flavors and treatments that is responsible for the distinct taste of their cigs. You can still find plenty of good quality, cheap tobacco (menthol, light, regular, extra bold, etc) but it will never be an exact match for your favorite brand.
Another thing is that these homemade ones will always burn just slightly differently than the industrial ones. Industrially made cigarettes are (AFAIK) made from a specially prepared reconstituted tobacco paper rather than shredded leaves. They do this to make things easier for their treatment steps, but also to make the mix have a 100% consistent texture and consistency that helps avoid problems with their processing and packing machinery. When you buy the cheap bags of raw tobacco, it's just leaves that have been cut/shredded to a consistency which is appropriate for rolling or tube packing cigs. So sometimes you may have a tiny inconsistency or packing error and wind up with a small void or an end of the tube that doesn't pack completely.

After you get familiar with the perfect amount of leaf to load in the machines chamber by doing a couple dozen cigs, you'll start to avoid this issue for the most part.

All in all, it's super cheap and easy to do and I'm always amazed that more smokers don't RYO

God damn I hate tubes, they are disgusting and overpriced as a motherfucker.

Anyway, a non-shit machine won't blink at any size you throw at it, it should effectively make no difference.
The little plastic shooters and mid-range one handed bandits are pretty shit, they struggle with everything and aren't worth your time.

If you're going to pop out almost 2 cartons worth per week, you're going to want something that'll keep up.
If you practice, and you get good and quick with a Top-o-Matic style injector or a handheld plastic one, sit down and do it all very rapidly in one sitting without taking a brake, that'll take about an hour.
If you aren't a spastic twat, and also aren't a fucking master of the tube injector, you'll more realistically be spending 2+ hours per week making smokes.

A decent electric filler will save you so much time and effort it's worth joking about.
I have a hard time getting excited about 'em as I despise tubes and I'm probably faster with my rolling box (which isn't hand rolling, it's a fucking machine to do the work for you) than most faggots with a tube shooter.
If you want quantity though, a good electric filler is hard to beat.
It'll pay for itself anyway with the savings on smokes, and it'll pay for itself twice over versus the headaches of cheap shitty options.

Most out there are chinkanese, and some do actually suffer with longer tubes like you mentioned.
Handheld Plastic and Lever-Handle injectors are designed for specific sizes, and rarely perform well with any other size.
An electric that has adjustable pack/fill and has an oversized fill rod that can easily clear sizes beyond 100, that's what you want.
See if you have any local tobacco shops, as opposed to a smokeshop, decent chance they'll carry the same ones you find in the tobacco catalogs and you can actually get your eyes and hands on them instead of throwing darts online.

posts.com: I use to have a few hand crank rollers, they're shit the nut always loosens and there is no torque specs on it, has to be so lose but just the right tightness that it holds the bar together but they can still move to get it to work. They work great for a bit of usage then always have the same problem. I ended up buying an electronic one for a hundred dollars to test it out. Broke even in cost within 2 months, and actually had beer money left over after that. I kept having to travel for work and going out of town it wasn't practical to ever make enough to bring with and it was noticeable how fast buying packs would burn through cash. Even though it takes 5 minutes to make a pack worth of cigarettes with it usually it isn't worth the time compared to a tobacco pipe for me personally. Your mileage may vary. It was more than worth it for me the machines worked for over 5 years now (way more than I ever got out of hand crank ones) it's nice to be able to knock out a few really fast if I'm in the mood for a cig, and they're convenient when walking around outside and it's windy on the way between the bar to pick up a few drinks. It can be difficult getting consistency in how tightly they're packed, with hand cranks you can pack a tube so tighly you basically can't keep it lit, electronic ones will jam and you can't force it and have to break it up and go with much looser packing in cigarettes, so you want to smoke them if you got them otherwise they'll tend to shake loose while you're walking around. It's not a big deal if you got a hard case you can just throw the shake back into the machine and repack it, tear off the empty part of the tube that it fell out, it can be annoying if you got like 3 half cigarettes, but you get a sense for which ones will do that and to smoke them first. If you care to carry rolling papers on you, you can always just use that shake to make a rolley too, I like a rolley when no pipe but it's hard not to burn my stache with them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2524402
>The powdered stuff that you snort. Dont know the name, never tried it.
That's snuff, and it's fucking awesome.

Ozona is the most widespread brand in the US.
Their Presidential is pretty unimpressive in my opinion, the Weiss and English are much better.
The C-Type (cherry) is what I'd recommend to most first-timers as an introduction to the stuff.
You sniff a small amount, a very small amount, into your nostrils.
Just the nostrils, you're not inhaling it, just barely getting it up in there.

Of every tobacco product out there that I've tried, snuff is the closest analogue to cigarettes as far as the high they provide.
You use very, very little tobacco, and it hits you like a freight train, then wears off quickly.
It's convenient as hell, a little tin in your pocket is much smaller than a pack of smokes and won't be ruined by manhandling, and you can use it wherever the fuck because it sure as hell isn't smoke, and that includes wherever the kids with vapes aren't allowed.

Ever needed a smoke in the middle of an unimpressive movie you're sitting through with some bitch?
Ever really needed a smoke on a long flight?
Stuck in a meeting for a whole day with one fucking lunch break and no chance to take 5 and puff one?

Go buy a tin of snuff from any decent tobacco shop, usually costs less than a half-decent pack of smokes.
I'm a pack-a-day smoker, and if I'm on a business trip I won't bother with smokes, a 5g tin of snuff lasts me 5 days.
It may not replace your current preference, it sure as shit has never replaced cigarettes or cigars for me, but it is a fucking awesome addition to the line-up.

It's also worth noting, it's basically guaranteed to make you sneeze.
You get over it quickly if you use the stuff regularly, but your first few times it's pretty much a certainty that you'll sneeze some nasty tobacco-laden ectoplasm.
Be ready with a tissue the first time you try it.

>>2523144
I smoked packs, hand rolled and made them with tubes and loose tobacco like that.

I prefer hand rolled. Packs are good but too expensive and honestly the additives in those cigarettes make them like 10 times more addictive. Like how you crave another cigarette right after smoking the first one. Don't have that with handrolled because it's pure tobacco. Pack cigs also have a sort of chemical flavour to it that you only really notice when you're used to hand rolled. Also way too expensive.

Machine made is a decent option although very messy and also an annoying task to do. Having to take extra time in the morning/before you go out/when the pack is empty to fill up another carton may seem like not a big deal but it really gets annoying after a while. It's also not a guarantee that every cigarette is going to be perfect. There's a certain learning curve to it where if you use too much tobacco the cigarette is impossible to smoke and if you use too little you smoke it in 10 seconds. Also annoying

Hand rolled are king imo. I smoke a 50gram pouch in a week with about 10-15 cigarettes a day. Comes down to about 45 euros a month on cigarettes, which to me is doable. Taste better and once you get the technique down right you can roll a perfect cig in under a minute, which is more convenient (to me) than having to machine out a whole pack every morning. Get a bag of those little filters and the rolling is much easier and the cigarette smokes nicer as well, no tobacco pieces in your mouth. Also nice for rolling the ocassional spliff.

When I go out to a party or a club though I'll usually just buy a small pack so I don't have to bother rolling a cig and can share with others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528681
I think the quality varies rather from model to model rather than the manufacturer, the only real difference would be lesser support for less common models. It would be best to watch reviews of a given model and see what features it has that you would need. The models in one price range are generally very similar with slight variation of features. Once you get to higher price ranges there will be better gimbals, more switches, color screens, support for more external modules and such, at least with OpenTX/EdgeTX radios. With that Betafpv radio you would need to upgrade when/if you get something else that runs on a different protocol, or needs a long range module.
Here's a list of radios that run on and are supported by Edge/OpenTX.
https://edgetx.org/faq.html
https://www.open-tx.org/radios

I was in charge at a tier 1 automotive company and we got a batch of about 2000 wire harness from Mexico where some were faulty but all required testing. The facility which produced the shitty harness also built a application specific continuity tester for this specific job, which also turned out to be faulty. >>2518885
It was the combination of a few factors, but the biggest one is called "dot gain". Colors are made by mixing size and location of dots in 4 different colors. Sort of like how digital screens mix RGB pixels together to create colors.

When you print those dots, there are factors that can make the dots larger or smaller than intended. In this case the paper it was printed on absorbed the ink more, creating larger dots. There might have been other factors, I don't know.

The ad was already very dark and moody looking to begin with. I did one quick pre-press at a local printer, and it came out dark... I had them lighten it a bit and due to time/money had to send the files right away.

I was really proud of the ad. It was my first "big" print ad, and I also handled the photography and design from top to bottom. Like, I was planning on framing a copy of it lol.

In another life when i worked in IT as an admin and coder, i mistakenly connected a standard null modem rs232 cable to a UPS. it shut itself down. Since a lot of loads were not load balanced to another source, they went dark, and there was probably write back cache enabled without bbu on some some servers. bringing everything back took 12 hours. there was a SAN but fortunately it did not suffer too much. Some backups had to be restored. file system integrity checks had to be performed. some files were lost and had to roll back to a day prior from backups. Always use the original APC serial cable. its written on the connector. Management took it well because fuck ups were extremely rare and I performed well.

ah hospitals... it reminds me one day when I worked at a large hospital network admin center some years ago. the fuck up was not my fault, but basically the fm200 fire extinguisher went off and the overpressure and accoustic and thermal shock fried a bunch of SAN disks and server disks. VMs had to be restored and some standalone servers for the radiology department were tricky to restore to functionality (they had too old backups) and dlls and what not had to be restored using the windows recovery console. it took a week or more to go back to normal. I then advised to use an hypoxic fire protection. the datacenter was inside the hospital campus so they could route some nitrogen if they really wanted to. I am not sure though if hypoxic fire prevention is as reliable to prevent all fire scenarii.

>>2530781
Blender is not capable of creating a live environment. Let's just establish that.

Unity is probably your best bet, or Unreal engine. They're designed to take input in a real time environment. But you have a steep slope ahead to get what you want.

There are simplistic platforms to get into for virtualized robots, like CoderZ, which is for teaching schoolkids how to learn robotics in a virtual environment, or the Virtual VEX Robot platform. Virtualized robotics are an active field of research and development.

I don't think you know exactly how much work is ahead of you, building it all from scratch. I would dive into the simpler forms of it like CoderZ and get a feel for how they build their platform, and then scale off that.

Anything beyond CoderZ and the like is going to be expensive and proprietry, because you could literally base an advanced degree on designing an environment you're describing, and could sell the results on the open market for quite a bit of money.

So the bottom line is, how much experience in coding do you have? If the answer is none, or a little - focus on that, there's no point going further.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530781
What you are describing is a CAM simulation. They can be as small as a single tool in material, to a production cell or above. The only real limit is hardware for simulation, and is it really feasible to simulatate to that detail. Mastercam is one, and FANAC makes another for their robot systems and cells.

They get very expensive, very quickly. The reason you only find very specific limited packages is that the amount of information you need to do a simulation can be eye wateringly specific.

As the anons said before, unity or unreal is where you are gonna wanna look, sonce they have the structures to get close the simulations you need, though the accuracy of calcs is gonna bite you in the ass if you are dependent on it. Take a look at the unreal assey marketplace on the epic store, and start saving every free file you can get your mits on, since they cycle what is free every few weeks. Some is optimized for simulation work that you can use for a starting point. Not sure on unity though.

Honestly, the more you learn, the more you will find there's a reason this is not mainstream yet, due to the web of computing power available in genric industrial environments, the web on IP bullshit (thanks Disney), and the simple fact of does simulation of more than just the tool paths make sense?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477882
Induction doesn't require material to be magnetic, just conductive. Energy transfer is more efficient when magnetic, but steel will become non-magnetic when sufficiently heated. If anything you would prefer a non-magnetic, non conductive crucible such that the metal is directly heated rather than indirectly through walls of crucible. Big challenge in getting up to temperature is all of the heat losses due to radiation and convection. For cast iron / cast steel graphite-based crucibles are most commonly used. Not straight graphite but don't know the exact formulation.

Oh, it's you. You need to learn thermodynamics. The steel furnaces are lined with ceramic liners (usually some cementatious clay). This + the steel's ability to be cooled by air is enough to avoid melting.

Whe the clay liner fails you get all the molten metal shooting out the hole in the now-melted steel.

The lid and liner are very thick relqtovely speaking; this insulates the melt inside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2488793
Most of the iridium on Earth (probably) ended up bonded to iron and is still molten beneath the crust, which is the reason there is so little accessible to us.
We do mine it, it does occur naturally, it's just rare stuff.
There's more of it in meteorites than in the layers of Earth we have access to, that's not unusual, that's true of numerous elements.
This makes it useful as one of the indicators of large meteorite impacts, one of many valid and observed indicators.
That's about it. It's useful stuff, been produced and used commercially for just shy of 200 years now.
It's just uncommon in the top layers of the Earth's crust where we can access it.

In the scale of the universe, it's an element with a fairly high atomic number (77), so it's going to be relatively uncommon compared to "most" elements with lower atomic numbers. This isn't a perfect rule, but it's a decent rule of thumb.
The reasons why are complex, you'd be wanting to read up on cosmic nucleosynthesis to get an idea of how various elements were formed by the Big Bang, exploding stars, merging stars, cosmic rays, all kinds of neat stuff. Isotopes and stability play a big role in this, certain elements don't have known stable isotopes, and are so "unlikely" to exist in nature they may well not exist anywhere in the universe they aren't actively being produced by an intelligence with the intention of producing them, like we do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2490205

The most viable iridium deposits on Earth are massive, fuck-off huge ancient impact craters from around the time the crust was forming an stabilizing. those are actually a big part of the reason Africa has so much mineral wealth in general. Outside of that, you find a some in old volcanic complexes that have eroded away.

You can pull "native" iridium from copper and platinum refining in minuscule amounts, or in very rare igneous deposits as microscopic bare nuggets alloyed with other metals. There's a couple iron-iridium minerals and one copper-iridium mineral that forms naturally as inclusions in deposits of other platinum and iron-group minerals, but they're vanishingly small - 5 - 10 micron in diameter, and very very sparse.

Basically, the tiny amount that we currently produce is all produced "accidentally" as a byproduct of refining other rare metals. most of the viable sources occur as a "side product" of mining gold conglomerates in Africa and gold sands in North America.

it's a damn shame, as iridium complexes might end up being some of the most compelling phosphors and catalysts ever discovered, but no one in their right mind is ever going to suggest large scale industrialization of an iridium-based chemistry. Even metallurgical uses are basically all luxury items at this point, with some very low volume extreme-condition industrial uses.

>>2496976
The power requirements are MASSIVE. Always used for small batch metallurgy or low melting temp metals that need VERY carefully controlled temperature profiles. Large batch Induction heaters are almost always used as reheaters or preheaters these days. Arc heating or gas fired is still preferred.

Induction smelters are great for fine control and quick batching but are more expensive than any other heat source.

>>2499296
Heat red hot. Oil quench with pliers no swishing (firing tip down). Heat at AT LEAST 500°F (more like 600 if you can) until it shows a good darkening yellow color.

That should give you a proper hardened profile with enough tempering to not explode.

Google search (O1 tool steel tempering graph) and aim for 50-55HRC if you want more info.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508422
Easy recipe: take some generic 1020 or 4140 or something (a proper quenchable tool steel if you are brave) and cut it into small chunks (or buy some steel shot if lazy). Take some cast iron powder. Pack the chunks VERY WELL and tightly into a crucible and seal it or at least borax the shit out of the top. Bring to half way between the melting temperature of the cast iron and of the steel.

The cast iron melts and diffuses into the steel. Eventually the chemistry of the steel and castiron average out until it is a mass of solid chunks and intermingled semi-solid mushy not-quite-cast iron. Consistency of a concrete that is a little too dry. You need to only heat it long enough to get this diffusion about half way - if it becomes 100% solid you went too long. Allow this to slowly cool so that everything diffuses well together but maintains a distinct pattern.

The steel you used is mostly the original steel (now higher carbon) but is all bound with a web of very carbidic pearlite, carbides, and other high-Si intermetallics.

>>2513066
Anything that is carbide forming (tool steels, bearing steels) resists carbon diffusion through martensite (huge Ni/Cr atoms + small Mn/V atoms fug up the diffusion) so you can develop a decorative oxide layer but maintain strength and hardness.

Look for "impact grade" tool steels if you're making a sword.
