>>2516112
Acid reacts with and rapidly corrodes the surface of metal. Can be used in combination with a resist to make some sort of pattern or just applied generally to expose virgin metal, as for weld testing.
You can get both sulfuric and hydrochloric acid from a well stocked hardware store. Sulfuric is sold as drain cleaner, and HCL is sold for cleaning concrete and masonry labeled as muriatic acid. Even the acetic acid in cleaning vinegar will work, albeit more slowly. Copper sulfate, which is sold for horticulture and aquaculture can also be used for etching, but I'm not sure of the specifics of the process.

>>2518598
With PLA I've had the best luck turning the mold upside down and melting at 400C. Then turn up to 450C which will cause anything left to burn out. The kitchen oven won't quiet do it, so I made my own out of a stovetop heating element, inswool, PID, and a washing machine drum. I found a 3D printing filament "Mold-Lay" that is low temp enough to be melted out in the kitchen oven, but still makes a smoky mess and more expensive than PLA. I usually use 50% sand 50% plaster. The 45 minute plaster works better than the 15 minute plaster (and is cheaper too). Use a paint brush to paint the mixture on the surface before fully submerging to make sure it fills all the nooks and crannies. Using 356 aluminum rather than potluck aluminum will give much better results (found someone on Ebay selling for $3/lb).

>>2521382
Instead of just putting a model in plaster and burning it out you make a multi-layered shell of porous ceramic glaze and essentially sand. You then can preheat the entire mold after burnout and fill with metal then let slow cool in the furnace.

The finer the model (wax is historically used for ease of burn out, modern SLA works great but takes longer to burn) the better the end product.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
Not sure if it's any use but I have a bit of experience. You shouldn't be seeing blue with just the fuel on, you also don't have to make a huge acetylene flame before lighting the oxy, I'd say once the flame has volume and is putting out thick black smoke then you're good for the oxy. When you're tuning the flame people talk about a neutral flame but it's kinda hard for a beginner to grasp what that means, basically you watch the little flame needle (or needles depending on your nozzle) sticking out the hole (or holes) in the nozzle tip, you want that needle to be as long as possible without the flame flickering or changing color, the base of the flame should be blue with the yellow and orange further out, if you try to make the needles too long the flame will become a bright white and jet out of the nozzle in a sort of thin beam so that's a good way to tell you that you went too far. Sometimes gauges are weird so I can't really help you there, used to have a gauge at the shop that would correctly read the oxygen psi at the pressures we needed but the needle would never drop below 20 psi even when we turned it off. Make sure you have a welding/brazing tip and use good filler, keep the filler shielded by the outer flame not the the inner needle and don't dip that needle into the puddle, that's pretty much it for mild steel, it's kinda like tig when you start going.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
>>inb4 don't weld with it

Whoever told you that was a moron. The little torches are great for sheet metal and light work. OA was the only way to weld aircraft parts before TIG was invented in WWII.

Get a copy of the Oxwelders Handbook, no later than 1939 which was peak OA welding era. They're about ten bucks online.

This forum is one of the last with quality OA welding and related equipment posts. It's noob friendly. https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/2-MIG-TIG-Stick-And-Oxy-Fuel-Welding/

Blacksmithanons will also enjoy this place: https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/121-Sticky-Forum

A shade 5 face shield is most comfy. Goggles are shit. Your local welding supply has them. Sunglasses also work well but I wear glasses and prefer shields which protect the face.

Determine what make/model torch you have. I buy tips via Ebay and only use US-made torches. Torches are typically cheap and I've got several from the 1930s I pressure tested (with clean compressed air) that sealed perfectly. Ivory soap is fine leak detector and recommended in old factory literature.

Don't sweat the gauge so long as you don't run too high a psi which for OA welding there is no need anyway.

PSI info and some background:
https://forum.millerwelds.com/forum/welding-discussions/7731-pressure-regulator-setting-for-o-a-cutting-and-welding

posts.sub: Does anyone use long range Wi-Fi? Why is download so slow but upload fast?
posts.com:
The first three paragraphs are information, the 4th is the question.

I have a wifi antenna reaching about 1/3 mile in an urban setting. I am connected to university wifi while off-campus, because I have a line-of-sight to the highest power wifi transmitter they own. A weak gigabit-speed signal outpaces closer free-wifi options and I have the benefits of not needing to verify my identity and access library materials using school wifi.

Only an area the volume of a baseball gets the signal I can't find it anywhere else as reliable... Someone had suggested local weather conditions (fog, wind, temperature) may affect connection dynamics but really the biggest thing is finding the signal's g spot, and fixing it there...

I have a signal between 29%-42% and the weather's entirely different now than last night. I use a simple aluminum foil reflector/shield and my window's aluminum blinds are pulled up. I notice I frequently switch between two wi-fi channels when connected to the tower thus the difference in speeds. One has download speeds of 0.1mbps to about 7.0, and the other one does between 5 and 18mbps... Both have upload speeds in the 30s so the downloading is the problem.

THE QUESTION: Assuming a fixed antenna, proper polarity, 1,676 feet distance (+/- 10 feet) line-of-sight signal to Wi-Fi channels 54 and 140, that can maintain a 13-65mbps connections (represented as 29-42% signal), what do you believe may be causing me to have such low download speeds, when the upload ones do just fine? Can I fix the download link to be as fast as the upload? My background is in FM/TV/CB radios so it loosely translates to Wi-Fi.

P.S. The university antenna I am connected to is practically empty of users because of winter break. And, I have established connection at 2/3 mile with line-of-sight, and detected signal from 3 miles with line-of-sight. I have thought about those factors

>>2534166

Your antenna is shittier than theirs, simply. You are able to receive packets transmitted to you, but with a significantly higher error rate than the other way around. This necessitates more retransmissions of lost packets, resulting in a lower overall speed. If you have LoS, using a parabolic antenna significantly better speeds in both directions.

Technically, it could also be a result of a symmetrical connection where most users are downloading, not uploading. Given the relatively small proportion of the school's total bandwidth that you're actually using, however, I seriously doubt that would result in such a large discrepancy for you.


>>2534349
>wireless ethernet.

"Ethernet", by definition, uses a wired (either copper or fiber optic) connection.

>connections that despite being wireless have the same low latency

Low-latency wireless data links do not magically become "wireless ethernet" simply for having low latency. You could, technically, spit out an ethernet signal between a pair of transceivers, but this is a horrible idea for numerous reasons and nobody does this because it's retarded.

POE powered dishes generally have less losses over the various cable runs and adapters and are weather-tight. You will want to mount any dish outside and high to avoid interference.

https://a.co/d/6ESvfUL

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534561
Good to see you got some improvement. I am going to guess your antennae are not covering the whole spread of channels - you got a high Q, narrow bandwidth response that happens to coincide with the uplink channels.

Multipathing can also be a problem where you have reflections and nulls causing dropped packets and a high re-transmission rate.

Urban environments are hell on GHz signals, hence highly directional antennae with wider bandwidths and medium gain may give better results.

You may be better off with a repeater mounted externally in an optimal position. A number of WDS devices that can be configured to do this.

A planer has the cutterhead on top for reducing the thickness of a board. A jointer has the cutterhead on the bottom to establish a flat and true surface. The thing about jointers/planers/tablesaws is that the length of board they can precisely cut is dependant on the length of the infeed table. These benchtop models have short infeed tables so I would face a board longer than a few feet on one.

Personally I'm just going to invest in a series of handplanes and figure them out.

I work outdoors often though I have garages and and collect things like large heavy cardboard boxes then remove staples and store them flat. Water is one thing but dirt and mud are far worse. Bin them after each job if you've no storage.

Europe likely has no trucks with them but if you can get a truck bed liner those are easy to cut up with a cordless angle grinder (every mechanic needs one) using a cutting disk. Rubber matting also works well and you can cut handhold holes into it. Have a strap so you can roll it up. Motorcycle friction style tiedowns work great for this.

For work off the ground I'd buy a folding canopy which are often used as sunshades etc in the Colonies.

A pail of water and jug of disk detergent makes it easy to clean your hands. Save small squeeze bottles like Sriracha and full with slightly diluted dish detergent for greater convenience. Plastic pails are great tool caddies and can be used afterward to clean tools.

>>2527235
Lots of kids end up in humanities literally just because math and science are so poorly taught in high school. By the time they are in high school, most kids dislike math and science because they think they're too hard. They aren't hard, they've just been failed in one or more topics. Failing is a normal part of learning any subject, but schools don't give kids time to go back and retry things they didn't master the first time. So kids just accept that they "don't know" x subject and have to leave it at that because it's time to move on. Teachers have curriculum goals that they have to meet so that when standardized testing rolls around, enough kids can give enough right answers to keep the school funded.

Subjects like language arts and history are a lot harder to fail, because there's less to get wrong, so kids end up thinking these subjects are the only things they are "good" at. These subjects are often tested with essays read by human proctors, which are way more forgiving than multiple choice math and science.

When it comes time to graduate high school, theres enormous pressure on kids to go to college and pick a major. They, logically, want to pick a major they are likely to succeed at, so using their limited window into education and job training, they arrive at the conclusion that they have to take humanities.

In an ideal world, kids would learn hard subjects at their own pace, and take as much time to master subjects as they need. >a significant portion of VHF/UHF activity these days is digital voice modes or other internet linking like AllStar, with most activity by users of those being radio -> repeater/node -> a server somewhere on the internet with no one else on that repeater/node at the time, rather than radio -> repeater -> radio
>a large number of people who use these digital modes do so via low power hotspots (normally running bluetooth level TX power) that they run themselves via their computer, reducing their radio to a fancy wireless microphone and speaker for their computer, with MMDVM hotspots that allow for people with analog radios to join in driving this point home even harder
>with few exceptions like DMR-MARC and small private servers that don't allow for hotspots, you can even communicate from end to end on many of these networks using a PC/phone client like DUDE-Star or DroidStar, without either party even touching amateur radio bands
How are amateur radio enthusiasts supposed to defend the bands from corporations wanting to gobble them up if this is how these bands are being used these days? posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mild steels above all else for high strength, low cost, ease of working, ease of welding, ease of repair, and availability. The majority of things are built from mild steels because it just plain works.

Aluminum can get fucked with it's brittle welds, higher cost, lower strength, and being harder to repair. It does have some use cases where it shines.

Wood is for furniture, houses, some buildings.

Concrete for floors, concrete pads, and foundations.

Basically they all have their use cases, but if I could only pick one to work with for the rest of my life I'd choose mild steel.

>>2526784
My fees broke down to cars being one price and SUV/Van/truck being a different price. I would either do the interior, the exterior or both. Interior I could usually do in 2 hours maybe 3. and exterior would take almost 4 hours. car interior was 100 and exterior was 125. For the van/truck/suv the fee was interior 125 and exterior 175. But this was 8 years ago, no idea what I would charge now

I had basic wash and wax stuff, and a machine buffer. For interior I had a vacuum and a steam cleaner. All my products were either meguairs or Griots. I always used microfiber cloths never rags. Microfiber cloths were thrown away after jobs I never washed them. On a full inside/outside I could usually get done in 6 or 7 hours. But if I had a van or something that was really fucked up it might take 8 hours.

Biggest tip is to take some before and afters and use social media as your word of mouth advertiser. Make damn sure that every single customer you work with posts something about you on either facebook or next-door and puts your phone number out there. Also get 500 flyers for your services off vista print.

No an LLC is a waste of time for the money you are gonna make. Just have them pay you cash and don't put the cash into the bank.

posts.com:
When that initial covid toilet paper thing happened, I got some Brondell bidet off Amazon. It was about $30 then. It's the bolt on kind, where you take the seat off to install it.
Works pretty well, I like it. Only two settings: spray your ass, and self-clean. That was more important to me than multiple nozzles, multiple water input/temp control, etc.

There's a "splatter shield" in front of the nozzle, and the nozzle only extends when you're using it. Uses the line pressure to extend, when you cut the water a return spring pulls it back up. The self-flush/clean does a good job, it's been low-maintenance.

Didn't use the toilet supply line, I ran off the sink's hot water. So there will be an initial room temp spray, then HOT lol. I did get toilet seat bump stops that are slightly taller (maybe 1/4"?) so I don't stress the seat when I'm sitting on it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2531643
If the city water is turned off (depressurized) then the poop water could be siphoned back into the city water system, leading to contamination. Certain weird cases such as fire hydrant use can also cause negative pressure in the pipes in your home.
You'll find that a lot of the codes, including the electrical and building codes, have to do with addressing edge cases where several unusual fault states are present at the same time.
>>2531683
I'm not that anon, but there are several code sections like Universal Plumbing Code section 603 which talk about back flow preventers. IDK if it's applicable to bidet hoses, but its an oversight if they haven't addressed it specifically in the code. The exact same mechanism of action that could lead to contamination from a pull down sprayer in a commercial sink or a garden hose could be found in these bidet hoses.

>>2504840
i'm an arborist by profession.
Even modern high quality chains break from time to time. either from misuse, accident or material fault. on average a chain snaps on me every one to two years. luckily modern chainsaws have a chain catcher under the clutch so even when a chain should snap it will immediately arrest on the catcher as it leaves the bar on the underside and be stopped at the catcher immediately - if you are lucky - just dropping down from the catcher harmlessly or slapping the hand guard on the rear grip where it will lose its momentum.
in the worst of cases one of the chain links will get caught and the rest of the chain will come whipping around on the underside of the bar - miss the hand guard and slap the underside of your rear arm, upper leg or your hip if you are holding the saw sideways.
in any case its going to be like a 35mph whip with teeth but it wont keep running and actually be pulled through your flesh as it hits you. wounds from this should be superficial due to the chain loosing most of its energy on the catch.

should you ever pick up a saw with this safety feature missing or damaged, do not use it!

It's still his most prized possession and he worries that we will sell it when he passes but I honestly intend to have it moved to my place, mostly for the planer, at least until I learn how to use the saw safely.

>There's a higher chance of error over an entire career than someone who makes two cuts.
You are conflating opportunity with probability...the opportunity to run your hand through a saw or vice versa exists each time you use one...that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable, but the opportunity to use that tool *without* an accident exists each time you use it as well. The total number of uses doesn't change that.
>>2523437
>Turns out when you do the same thing over and over as a career, you get complacent and overconfident.
Maybe you do, but witnessing the repercussions of bad decisions and truly unforseeable mishaps like tool and material flaws creating instantaneous danger and havoc makes lots of people far more cautious and methodical in their work, and far less likely to succumb to ridicule or pressure from higher ups to cut corners.
>And it also turns out that when you do something for a job, you get tend to get tired and your mind wanders.
Again, speak for yourself...if anything people with lots of experience know better when to take breaks or stop when fatigued, and understand better than anyone how to stay focused and why it's important.
You're just pulling stuff out of your ass to support your personal biases and assuming that correlation equals causation when it comes to experience and industrial accidents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523532
>that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable
yes that is literally how statistics work, if you have a p chance of not cutting your finger off and n number of opportunities to cut your finger off then the probability that in your life you cut your finger off is p^n. This function approaches 0 and for a sufficiently large n always ends with you cutting your finger off. Having a larger number of times where you don't cut a finger off is not going to undo the one time it does happen.

Jack safety is easy with cribbing as you go, I use my forklift jack to raise shipping containers when I add one to my shop (whose foundation is suitably large I-beams) and to put pipe rollers beneath. I also use classic Simplex mechanical jacks, the best being an early 1900s 329 telephone pole jack they still manufacture today. The chain grab is insanely handy:

https://www.ebay.com/itm/155277421886

6x6, 4x4, 2x4 and misc flat steel stacked as I go mean the jack could vanish and I'd be in no danger.

Wood cribbing has excellent traction on steel (the reason for placing a board between forklift forks and milling machine rams when lifting) and doesn't crush. The Air Force stores Mark 84s on wood dunnage in the field.

> they're either corroded
I had forgotten about the almost magical ability of Torx, Allen and other non- phillips/slotted drives to prevent corrosion in metal, and how much easier they are to clean out to a useable condition when painted over or filled with dirt, road grime and other debris, glue/mortar/stucco, etc. Super tight tolerances and tiny inside corners that lock that shit in are just the ticket when you want ease of removal, and Iike you said, only Phillips and slotted screws corrode so you don't have to clean that shit out just to get a driver into the female portion of other drive schemes. What was I thinking?
> or made of the weakest shit ever and it was a miracle that the screw made its way into the hole in the first place
Again, how silly of me to ignore the fact that as the relative shear resistance of metal decreases due to the type selected or deterioration in the field, the better it is to have a close tolerance drive mechanism that locks in and applies maximum torque and keeps it as centered as possible rather than spread across the head of the fastener so it gains leverage that can be finessed to gently break the fastener loose rather than instantly snapping the head off, or snapping the driver bit in two if the fastener is strong, or smoothing the corners/splines off of the bit or the hole like an end mill....or possibly all of the above. GREAT point.

Finally, who hasn't had a screw head deteriorate or be so full of garbage or just be too soft a metal to where it doesn't function for removal, and then used a file or Dremel or hacksaw blade to cut a superior Torx or allen or square drive hole in it as a last resort that saves the hassle of having to drill it out?
Or needed to remove a screw in a pinch when no real tools were handy and breathed a sigh of relief when the screw head was a Torx or square drive?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528132
>The biggest problem is autistic faggots assuming that one or two drive configurations can and should cover every possible combination of other factors

But there SHOULD only be a few. Ignoring security fasteners (which are homogay to begin with), there really should only be like four, max:

Spline has the highest torque capacity of any internal drive, but requires tight tolerances in order to work properly. If it slips, it's ruined.

Hex/torx are almost as good as spline, but is slightly more forgiving on tolerance.

Robertson/square is, again, slightly less capable than hex/torx, while being more usable in the case of fastener corrosion or damage.

Slotted is objectively fucking terrible, and should never be used. Its only saving grace is that you can easily turn all of the other really shitty fasteners into slotted, obviating the need for special drivers that you will never use again.


The rest should not exist, don't @ me. If you've got some niche scenario in which you "need" some other kind of screw, it's probably because you made some shitty other design decision. Fix THAT instead of making a new meme drive type.

>>2529235
>torx screws
>one bit is a perfect fit in all

WTF?
The main drawback of Torx is the need for separate drivers for each size and the extremly limited-to-non-existant ability to substitute anything else.
If all you ever do is bench/garage type work in controlled conditions then needing a complete set of graduated tools may not be a big deal, but in the field and/or in extreme conditions shit happens; tools break, fall over the side of a boat or into a tiny crevice , you need more than one at the same time, etc.
Three sizes each of straight blade or phillips drivers can handle a wide size range of both fastener types, and the straight ones can often work on the phillips too...AND sometimes will even work on a square or Torx or allen drive fastener in a pinch.
Although it should also be pointed out that all those drives being praised as superior because "they don't strip" also make it FAR more likely that careless morons will drive them in way too hard and often without any lube/ anti-seize or pilot hole or other considerations that make screws easier to install and remove without over torquing them and damaging the drive mechanism.
Straight slotted screws are used in precision mechanisms like watch movements in large part because they force you to be hyper aware of what you are doing and to have your tool in perfect alignment at all times and to never over torque the screw.
Phillips were designed to cam out rather than snap the heads off or damage the workpiece or gall when installers were moving fast.

But in any case, when fasteners are hard to remove without damaging them it's more often than not the result of careless installation, and the people whining about Torx and square drive being superior in all cases are crying because the fastener industry and product designers won't accomodate their laziness and lack of skill and PATIENCE that causes them to be defeated by the two simplest and most user friendly screw fastener drive schemes ever made.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Philips heads are more moden, they're harder to machine, harder to machine drivers for. But are centering and still decently rounding resistant.
Slotted is the grandfather of them all, dead simple to cut a notch in the screw and file/hammer down a driver. However it is not centering like the philips is and prone to having the driver slip. It is the single most rounding resistant aside from the spanner which doesn't even interface with the cuts unless properly engaged.
Slots still shine in very tiny applications. Like watchmaking where accurate machining/stamping of screws that tiny is not practical, and you generally have a machine putting the screes in anyways.

Chances are im entirely incorrect but this is what I've gathered in the thread and in real world experience

>>2529896
If you ate doing a repair or wall modification that requires taking g down drywall, even if you cut/break out the panel itself you still need to remove screws and if the wall was taped and finished they are all covered in drywall mud. Besides being fast to index and drive in an application where you only use a fraction of available torque anyway, phillips also has the advantage of the pointed nature of the bit naturally working to displace and eject the dried mud in the slots enough to get a bite, unlike other drives that engage in their hole like a piston and just pack that shit in tighter, and require a pick to remove debris.
Phillips is the perfect drive for drywall screws, which need removing pretty regularly.

Better question: How often do you need to remove the roll cage in a Mopar era Jeep, or the front and rear bumpers?
And why, in discussions of the rare occasions where this is necessary, do the words "torch", "grinder" and "air hammer" come up so frequently?

Here's a hint: the answer rhymes with "dorks".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I was a young child my father had a screwdriver he brought home from work, and he called his magic screwdriver. It was obviously a flathead in a previous life, but he had filed the end into something new altogether, a driver that he claimed would turn ANY screw. I am currently 24 years old and I'm yet to find a screw this driver can't handle, no matter the shape, or the amount of stripping. I genuinely believe this screwdriver can never be replicated, not by any other man, or machine, one driver to rule them all. I know where it lives even to this day, in my dad's "various useful junk" drawer, in his kitchen, waiting for the next challenge, maybe even an old rusty allen bolt, who knows.

I love my father, but sometimes I sit up at night, wondering how much longer I have to wait. When I will get the call or the letter, informing me that I can finally claim what is mine, my birthright, and destiny. The greatest screwdriver that has ever been, and ever will be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530137
I've used auto-feed screw guns both for phillips drywall screws and installing wood and composite decking with square drive screws and in real world use the ability of the phillips to cam *in* as the fastener is indexed and locks into the drive makes for FAR more trouble free operation and less need to replace bits that aren't in perfect condition.
When you're doing fast repetitive driving, even with a clutch the pressure and motion on the square drive bits as they come out of the hole tends to round them off in a way that makes them more likely to not register with subsequent fasteners and misfire, which fucks the top up more.
The tapered nature of the Phillips profile can get spun smooth at that entry point and still let the tool pop right into its slot.
Also in non automated settings square drives used to back out tight fasteners can develop a twist that makes them harder to engage and weakens the tool.
For all the frustrations Phillips can be a part of, having a tool snap off in the slot and be galled in place because of the effort applied to try to back it out isn't one of them. Can't say that for Torx and square drives, that can snap off flush or below the head's surface and become their own project.

Eh. DIY is about getting exactly what you want. DIY is the OG Innovator & Inventor. It may or may not take more time and be a greater hassle than hiring someone else. That depends on you and your tradesmen (no refunds for shitty work). If you do your research and develop your skills, then your work can rival that of a professional, but more importantly, it may just stand the test of time. Cost-cutting is simply a byproduct of a more efficient use of resources (cut out the middle-men). The result of this is a temptation to spend extravagantly on higher quality materials, components and equipment. Which I would consider a perk. In the end, the DIY Man exists a dimension marked by an uneven and changeable skill-floor in stark contrast to a truly limitless skill-ceiling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530159
Artificially aging your tools is pretty cringey. That's the equivalent of "distressed jeans," which is something no decent tradesman owns.
>Exception: hard hats. If you buy a new hard hat, drag it through the sand to take the shine off it. At least where I work, guys will actively harass other guys on site if their hard hats or hi-viz look too new.

You're not asking about this, but CONDITIONING your tools increases their lifespan and is a mark of professionalism. Rusty, splintery, poorly cared for tools are the mark of either a fucktard or a poser and you need to steer clear of them.

To condition your wooden tools, use a plane to take off the varnish and apply linseed oil. If your tool handle is oversized, you can use your plane to give it an octagonal shape which many old trades guys swear by for comfort. Allow it to cure completely, then apply at least one layer of Walrus Brand tool oil, both to the handle and to the steel head of whatever tool it is. If your tool (or PPE) has leather components, use Obenauf's leather oil and conditioner. If the tool is rusted, use steel wool or another abrasive to remove excess rust and restore remaining rust with 30% vinegar. If you're going to paint your tools, use the highest quality enamel paint you can get your hands on and follow the instructions else it will not last. Should your tool have moving internal parts, the manufacturer likely recommends specific products to lubricate with, and there are many different kinds of lubrication and grease that vary in their intended use (temperature/climate, use severity, etc).

So why am I telling you about restoring and conditioning your tools if you're interested in being a poser? Because you'll have tools that look like someone cares for them, even if nobody's using them for their intended purpose, and that will make them "more characterful" than any amount of fake patina or artificial aging could ever achieve.

>>2530271
Should do lug nuts 90% of the time. I had a 450lb rated brushed corded guy and it would do lugs on passenger cars as long as they weren’t rusted on or way overtorqued by a tire shop. Also impacts in general are handy for shit that’s difficult with hand tools, like stuff that wants to move or spin when you put torque into it, mower blades being a common example and now you can remove lugs while the car is in the air.

The thing with the new brushless ones is they’re way more compact. You can get more torque in something half the size and the big ones will break loose shit that has you bending breaker bars and yelling like a sailor.

Being able to pull off wheels without cracking the lugs loose on the ground will make you love it. Saves a bunch of time whenever you need to remove and reinstall 4 wheels.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2531775
It will probably work for the grinder. That’s exactly the situation where impacts shine, when you’re having a hard time keeping something in place. Like I was watching my boomer neighbors struggling with the blade on an edger for an hour because it’s hard to jam the blade up and the bolt holding the blade hadn’t been removed in years, but wasn’t like super tight or rusted. I grabbed the little 3/8” stubby which isn’t any more powerful than what you can do by hand with a 1/2” ratchet, but I held the blade of the edger with one hand and spun the bolt out in 2 seconds.

If you end up with a real big truck, the high torque 1/2” cordless guns will normally do those, but most truck shops with Class 8 shit use a 1” impact wrench. I’ve talked to diesel mechanics who use the big 1/2” on truck lugs and it works most of the time but makes the wrenches die a premature death because it’s a struggle for them.

>45 degree
Not sure about that. The higher on the pole the guy wires the stronger the leverage, but also the further on a 45° angle. Leverage works two ways, so the stronger, the stronger wire is required. The further on each the more stretch is introduced. Ground space and wire length are not usually unlimited. I think something around 60% up would be more efficient as you're dealing with inertia as well. It's a second year engineering problem, maybe pt6 it to /sci/

Gearwrench and Sunex will both sell you nice impact sockets for a reasonable price. If you go on Amazon, SATA is basically an Amazon house brand made by GW and there are some deals to be had on those sets. >>2530328
The secret is that those wood pilings are submerged all the time. Without any oxygen able to get to the wood they last perfectly well for decades.
Other examples are the pilings houses stand on in the Netherlands or those supporting the Speicherstadt in Hamburg Germany.

For wood pilings it is vital that they're submerged all the time. The oxygen starvation prevents or heavily delays the decomposition processes.

Best example is now in the Netherlands those same wood pilings. Due to the heavy dewatering of the low laying areas for pasture the soil itself drops down exposing the pilings themselves at the top causing them to rot right under the brick walls.

There's an old dude on Ambergris Caye who's the last remaining fisherman in the area permitted to harvest live conch from the reefs. Every day he goes out and gets a haul of conch, then putters his boat over to the same spot where he's been cleaning them for decades. He pops them out of their shells, and tosses all the shells overboard, to the point that the spot is a shallow area from the tens of thousands of accumulated conch shells.
He makes middling money from selling the meat to restaurants, but the wild thing is that he could set up a 20 sqft stall in San Pedro and sell these shells to tourists for $50-100 apiece, easily. Could probably make 10x his current income, even accounting for the retail space rent and the cost of hiring someone to staff it full-time, but he just throws the things away. My mom traded him a cold soda for a shell the size of her head.

>>2530735
It's still garbage. The ring pull tab isn't ancient, it was invented in the 1950s. It was discarded because drunks could swallow the tabs and they could cause cuts when sat or stepped on.

Prior cans used "can openers".

A can in collectible condition will be straight, externally undamaged with at most minor scratches or fading. Best are those left so long they dried out without the tab being pulled.

So which tool brand is the best?

For me? It's going to have to be RYOBI™. With 260 innovative product solutions to choose from, RYOBI™ provides the ultimate in versatility and selection to get the job done. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I own about a dozen ryobi tools, the 18v line
Leaf blower is underpowered, only works well on loose completely dry leaves
Hedge trimmer works well but snags and seizes on 1/2" twigs (not that its built for those)
Branch saw is ok but telescoping parts are awkward. Can't cut much more than 1.5" thick
Chainsaw is ok for chopping up 1-4yr saplings and anything under 4" thickness. Anything bigger and you need two batteries and cut it from every side. Chain loosens too easily
Air pump is shitty and the attachment holder clips for it are bad design
Weed wacker is fine for small yards and normal edging, completely fails at real weed growth and anything wet/thick. I need two large batteries to do my lawn. The feed mechanism is CANCER. It auto feeds every time you pull trigger, so if you want to spot trim areas, you can't just release and pull, you have to just keep it pressed or else you'll be constantly feeding line out
Brad nailer is fine
Drill and impact drill are fine
Dremel is good not great, a little underpowered. Used it for polishing feed ramps on some guns
Batteries are overpriced as fuck. Chink shit from amazon 1/4 the price and work good enough.
I have two sanders i havent used yet but i presume same case of "good enough" for small jobs but not for big ones.

I was a municipal inspector for six months to complete my education. I mainly monitored commercial service installation (sewer/water). My tasks included giving the contractors layouts for how deep to dig and what elevation to set the pipe, then take as-built measurements of the construction and send them to the engineer.

If you want to be in the thick of it, you kinda have to have a job in the field (ie a reason to be on site in the first place) otherwise you'd be a liability and, lets face it, a nuisance to the workers because frankly they just want to do their work and go home.

>>2534546
Its been almost a year since I left that job, and I haven't spent that much time in industry, so take my answers with a grain of salt. And for context I'm a leaf.

>Any ideas for getting a temp job then?
Generally the position I had is offered to those either completing education or is educated and is building experience towards certification. Engineering firms would rather trust someone with ANY civE education than someone who "just like the field". Proof of education shows some level of commitment and employers (the good ones) want to mutually contribute to their own productivity and to the growth of their emplyee's careers.

>What difficulties do you have with overcoming water table constraints?
Unfortunately I can't answer this question but what I have seen with ground water infiltration is that the workers will just dig out a sump pit, and have a pump running while they work.

Do you get leeway for using pre-fab components?
I don't know what pre-fab components you are thinking of, but sewer and water pipes are mass produced and I see the same company's logo on various jobs I've been on. Manholes are made of concrete and made to order because they need to meet a certain elevation when installed. Goes without saying but manhole covers, curb inlets etc. are also mass produced. Fire hydrants are mass produced, but the stack that connects to the main line is manufactured to lenth for the same reason manholes are made to order.

>Do you ever encounter any issues post-compaction?
Installed services must pass tests from the city before being in commission. Pressure test for water and flow test for sewer. One time we had a sewer being tested and they noticed a section of the line was bowed and the pipes were oval shaped. I don't know the exact reason this happened but this was in the winter and the solution was to use heated sand to tamp around the pipe and backfill as usual. This was after they had already backfilled before the testing fyi.

posts.com:
I quite like bum spots for bmx trail/mtb riding. And I really like building/maintaining them.
One time we built a spot on city land, a little spit of land where the river was redirected by a dike. Very sandy soil, and we used "geotextile" to make it work. I didn't pay for it, a friend who worked at a concrete/landscaping place hooked me up with the remainder of a roll. It was kinda similar to "blue tarp" material, similr woven pattern, but this was black & narrow.

I think this guy has an annoying voice, but the visuals here get the point across
Practical Engineering - Sand Castle Holds Up A Car! - Mechanically Stabilized Earth
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0olpSN6_TCc

>>2532351
Looking at your sketch, you could probably get reasonable results using some kind of fabric with that technique.

You can also mix in "some concrete" as a stabilizer. Like a 10:1 soil:concrete ratio. It kind of acts like glue for the soil, and it's quite hard once you tamp it & it sets. That was useful for smaller features, and stuff that wore down fast. Doesn't feel good to land on, it's like the hardest packed dirt.
You don't have to mix it well (like with a wheelbarrow or something), cutting the cement powder in with a rock rake is good enough. Where I am, the natural moisture in the soil made it set.

My guess is your switch is used as a junction point to power both the light/fan and the switch in the other room. It’s pretty common to do so (though normally one wouldn’t use the switch itself for that, but a 3-way cable connector clamp or screw terminal).
There’s probably a splice in either the fan or the light box (whichever is closest to the switch, or some additional box) to power both the fan and light from the red wire.
If you want to separately switch them you would need to run an additional wire from your switch to that box.

Sorry if I messed up the terms, English isn’t my first language

posts.com:
For many people and projects, they are a poor source of lumber.
However, they are not useless.

The GOOD - They are often free for the taking and they are often hardwoods

The BAD –
Their size limits their usefulness.
They are often aged or damaged.
They are more awkward to haul home than a stack of boards.
They require disassembly.
They do not all use the same sized boards, you have to find matching pallets to get a bunch of boards that are all the same dimensions.
They sometimes are treated with Methyl Bromide, which is a health risk.
They have nail holes, often quite noticeable.
Sometimes they have unknown substances spilled on them from leaks.
It is a hassle to make them not look like pallet wood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pallets are stamped, but not on every board.
Only some pallets have risky chemicals, many are plain wood.

Pallets stamped HT are heat treated and safe to burn.
Pallets marked MB contain Methyl Bromide and should NOT be burned.

>Methyl bromide is a fumigant used to control pests in agriculture and shipping. Methyl bromide also depletes the ozone layer. Therefore, along with other countries, the United States has phased out production and consumption of methyl bromide with important exceptions for critical uses as well as quarantine and pre-shipment.
https://www.epa.gov/ods-phaseout/methyl-bromide

Is there a safe way to get these carcinogens out/off of the wood? Not to my knowledge.

Easy rule of thumb if they are MB or you don’t know for sure.

Don't Burn Them!
Keep the sawdust out of your lungs and off of your skin. This applies to all sawdust, actually.
Don't make cutting boards or other things that touch food.
Paint will seal them if you are still worried about excessive contact.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Using pallets intact has some applications, especially if you can find them the same size. I have seen furniture, animal pens. and greenhouses made from them. (The furniture is usually pretty ugly.)

MB-treated boards make decent outdoor planter boxes and other rustic things like shelves for your shipping container shed to store imitation crab meat.

Taking it apart isn't hard if you have the right tools.

If you are going to salvage a whole bunch of pallets, consider getting a specialized prybar. I would prefer to get one locally, so I could try it out to see if it is worthwhile, then be able to return it easily if it is crap.
https://www.1001pallets.com/top-7-best-pallet-buster-pallet-breaker-reviews/

https://www.99pallets.com/pallet-projects/diy-storage-shed-from-pallets/

This is unlikely to become a Sticky, so please help it stay on the board by posting pics of your projects and links to pallet idea websites that might inspire others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pallet Parts and Terminology

Annular Ring Nails (also called Ring Shank) – These are one of the most common types of fasteners used in pallet design. In essence, it is a nail with circular ring threads on the shank.

Banding Groove – Dunnage with a groove cut into the length of the lumber. It is used to protect unit loads from damage when banding is tightened down to secure a load onto a pallet.

Blocks – A square or rectangular piece of wood that is placed between the pallet decks or beneath the top deck. Some blocks can even be cylindrical. Generally, blocks are located at each corner of a pallet, centered on each of the four sides, and in the middle of each pallet. Placement is crucial to ensure block pallet strength.

Block Pallet – A type of pallet that uses blocks to form its base instead of stringers.

Bottom Deck – The deck boards on the bottom of a pallet that are sitting on the ground or floor.

Butted Deck Board – The name given to an inner deck board that is attached to an adjacent deck board during assembly to help strengthen it. These are often used when recycling pallets and pallet parts.

CAD – Stands for Computer Aided Design and helps pallet designers design packaging solutions.

Chamfered Deck Boards – Deck boards with the edges beveled. They are usually only beveled on one or two faces, and allow pallet jack wheels to enter the pallet more easily.

Collar – A wooden container or bin that turns a pallet into a box.

Container Bin Pallet – This is basically a crate, box, container, or four-sided structure mounted on a pallet base.

Deck – The boards or panels that make up the top or bottom surface of a pallet.

Deck Board – The component boards or panels that make up a deck.

Deck Board Spacing – The distance between deck boards on a deck.

Deck Board Span – The distance between the deck board supports. Could refer to the distance between stringers or blocks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Deck Mat – The assembled deck boards and stringers that make up the deck of a block pallet.

Deflection – The amount of bending or deformation in a pallet under load. Could refer to the whole pallet or a specific pallet part.

Double Face Pallet – A pallet built with both top and bottom decks.

Economic Life (of a pallet) – The number of trips a pallet is expected to make in its serviceable lifetime, provided that it remains properly repaired.

EURO Pallet – Block pallets built to European Pallet Association specifications. They usually have a branded logo on them.

Fastener – A component used to join pallet parts together, such as nails, screws, bolts, or staples.

Flush Pallet – A pallet where the deck boards are even or flush, with the stringers or blocks along the sides of the pallet.

Fork Entry – The opening between decks and beneath the top deck of a pallet where forklift forks can be inserted to lift the pallet and load. Sometimes stringers will have notches in them to allow for fork entry.

Four-Way Block Pallet – A block pallet that has openings on all four sides of the pallet to admit pallet jack entry.

Four-Way Stringer Pallet – A stringer pallet that has notches cut in the stringers to allow for pallet jack entry.

GMA or Grocery Manufacturers of America – Thee GMA has its own specific pallet requirements for its standard pallets.

Hardwood – The type of wood that comes from deciduous trees. Generally, these are the trees with leaves instead of needles, but there are exceptions. Although called hardwood, that doesn’t necessarily mean that it’s hard or dense. It depends on the species of tree the wood comes from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Inner Deck Board – Any deck board that is positioned between the end deck boards.

Joint – The point at which the components of a pallet intersect or connect. They are often identified as the end joint, center joint, and corner joint.

Length – In general, this is the first dimension given to describe a pallet and refers to the stringer or stringer board length. For example, a standard 48” x 40” pallet length is 48”, and is also the length of the pallet’s stringer.

Line Load – When the weight of a unit load is concentrated in a narrow area across the full length or width of a pallet.

Load Bearing Surface – The area of a pallet in contact with and supporting the weight of the unit load.

Multiple Use Pallet – A pallet designed to be used for several trips with different unit loads.

Non-Reversible Pallet – Describes a pallet where the bottom deck boards are configured differently from the top deck boards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Notch – A cutout in the wood of a pallet part. It could refer to something like the notch in banding groove, or the notch in a notched stringer.

Notched Stringer – On a pallet, this is a stringer that has notches cut out of it to allow entry for forklift tines. The notch is usually ½” to 1” in depth and 9” long, depending on the size of the pallet.

Opening Height – This refers to the vertical distance between decks on a pallet. It’s measured from the floor to the top of the stringer notch, or from the floor to the underside of the top deck.

Overhang – The distance that the pallet deck extends past the outer edge of the stringer or stringer board. It’s also called a wing or lip. Overhang can also refer to the distance that a unit load extends beyond the pallet deck.

Pallet Life – The length of time that a pallet remains useful. It’s usually expressed in the number of one-way trips that the pallet is expected to make or in units of time.

Panel Deck Pallet – A pallet constructed with some type of paneling product (OSB, composite, etc.) for the top deck.

PDS – Stands for Pallet Design System and is a computer aided design program that helps engineers to design pallets to safely carry a load and maximize the supply chain.

Recycled Pallet – A previously used pallet that is recycled and has been repaired for reuse with replacement pallet parts as needed. It’s also referred to as a refurbished or reconditioned pallet.

Remanufactured Pallet – A pallet that’s been built from reclaimed pallet parts. Sometimes they are also built from a combination of new and reclaimed pallet parts.

Skid – A pallet with no bottom deck that rests on the stringers. It’s a little like a sled on rails.

Slave Pallet – A support base for a palletized load in rack-storage facilities or production systems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Softwood – Softwood comes from evergreen trees. Generally, they have needles instead of leaves, but there are exceptions. The term softwood does not necessarily mean that the wood is a soft wood.

Solid Deck Pallet – Refers to a pallet that is constructed with no spacing between deck boards.

Span – The distance between block supports, stringer boards, or stringers.

Stevedore Pallet – Designed for seaport shipping docks, this pallet is designed with heavy-duty, double-wings.

Strapping – Flat, thin bands that are used to secure a load to a pallet. Often used with banding groove.

Strap Slot (also called a Banding Notch) – The notch or cutout on the bottom edge of the top deck board or the top edge of a stringer. It allows for strapping or banding to tie down a unit load.

Stringer – A solid or notched piece of lumber that is used to support the deck components on a pallet. Stringers run perpendicular to the deck components and there is usually one on each side of the pallet and one in the center.

Stringer Board – Refers to the solid boards that extend the full length of a block pallet and run perpendicular to the deck boards. Stringer boards are placed between the deck and the blocks.

SYP – Stands for Southern Yellow Pine, and it’s the wood most often used in wood protective packaging.

Take-It-Or-Leave-It Pallet – Refers to a pallet with fixed cleats on the top deck that provide a location for forklift tines to get under the unit load and lift the load off of the pallet.

Top Cap – A panel that is placed on top of unit load to protect it from strapping.

Two-Way Entry Pallet – A stringer pallet that does not have any notched stringers. Forklift tines can only enter the pallet on the ends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Unit Load – The palletized goods sitting on a pallet.

Wing Pallet – A pallet with the top and bottom deck boards extending past the edge of the stringers. Can also be a double-wing pallet if both sides extend past the edge of the stringers. Wing pallets can be single wing or double wing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Actual glass fabricator here.
Tempered glass is not the go to material for table top whether in a frame or with floating edges, because it doest like edge damage *at all* and also doesn't like concentrations of heat like you get in typical table uses.
Tempered glass is notorious for shattering with small concentrated point impacts and tables get those all the time from dropped utensils, tableware, etc.
The other thing is that tempering has to be done after any edge profiling is done so doing it risks all that labor. It's also done in an oven and can leave marks where the glass is supported and other imperfections that don't work well with something that needs optical clarity like a display case.

The way you get table capable glass strength is by using thick annealed glass, and 1/4"-5/16" is perfect for that kind of perimiter framed box, but not thinner. 1/2" is adequate for free standing di ner table and desk tops up to about 48" in any dimension and after that it starts to sag under its own weight.

Bottom line is that if a glass table or desk or display case breaks from dropping something on it you dont want everything else on it to dump at once into a pile of glass bits. If you chip an edge with annealed glass you can re-grind it or polish it out or cut a strip off, tempered just explodes.

90% of fireworks can be made with either black/gun powder or sugar + potassium nitrate

if you want color add some copper powder

use rolled paper and glue, not cardboard, and air dried clay for any nozzles or caps

soak string in the potassium nitrate mix + water and let dry to make fuses

use a face shield and your least favorite hand while putting stuff together

if you can't figure out where to source any of this, or research the proper ratios then you're too young to be doing this

This worries me too. I'm still using a 34 year old microwave oven, while all my friends have gone through multiple ones already.

For anyone saying "just buy quality", of many products there aren't quality products anymore, and even less for middle-class prices. In Finland tools are still pretty good, but hand showers are a great example of this: Only products available are 10€ ones that start leaking after five or so years, and 300€ ones. No middle ground.

But in cars the decline is well known and documented. They rust faster than ever before, are nigh-irreparable to the point that users aren't expected to fill their tires for themselves, and are chock-full of fragile electronics, which itself is more and more centralized into parts that cripple the entire car if they aren't replaced in their entirety.

Bosch for one used to be a manufacturer whose products were worth the investment, but now whores its brand name for chinesium-quality products. It's on a death spiral, and once boomers who grew up trusting it die no one will know it as anything but overpriced crap.

Hey OP, I've made the same observation. Although, I've figured out how to navigate the sea.

If you're interested in finding something of quality, head to eBay and search for what you're looking for, apply a filter of used, and sort from highest price first.

The things you're looking at are going to be the best of the best, in pristine quality. Narrow your search down to the think you want by researching for the specific name of what you're looking for now that you know what it is.

The problem isn't that the products don't exist anymore, the problem is that it's a hyper fractionalized market and the tools you're looking for are not competing in the advertising space. Good luck

"Brick" describes a modular masonry unit, not one particular material...and the process used to make them goes from no firing (adobe) to low firing (terracotta) to high fired structural brick that's essentially vitreous and similar to igneous stone.

Also, while concrete bricks aren't fired in a kiln, the component materials in cement are, and the curing process is exothermic.
The cement in concrete is made primarily from sedimentary rock (limestone) that has been fired to a higher temp than terracotta bricks are fired at.

"The products of the chemical reaction aggregate together at their sintering temperature, about 1,450°C (2,640°F). "

If she's making $150k a year, you can definitely afford a house. Life style creep is real and hard to deal with. I made 120k while my wife made 35k but now she's making close to 80k and keeps buying more bullshit. Most women are fucking retarded with money.

I use a budget tool, the one I use is You Need A Budget. I religiously tracked every expense and categorized them, and after 6 months I showed my wife what we spend our money on. Every month I sit her down and we go over what we want to budget. We can afford a $2700 mortgage and over $3000 in child care (2 kids now). We almost max out 401k's as well but have up on IRA.

It took some rough uncomfortable talks to get her to calm the fuck down with her money and make her understand that if we pay the mortgage every 2 weeks instead of monthly we will pay it off 7 years early. It took some time to show her how much we needed to save if we want to retire at 60.

You are her partner. Don't belittle yourself for making less. You can look for a higher paying job maybe on the coast where she "works" now. There may also be a tech bust sooner or later. It sucks, but you need to make her understand you're a team, have a discussion about what HER goals are, and help her reach them. If she's spending like this maybe she doesn't care about a house. Get your goals situated and help her come up with a plan.

First off, your post and other anons' posts in this thread are saddening to read. You should also talk with your wife about your finances, how you plan to budget for necessary expenses, etc; but don't talk to her in a patronizing way about it. You both should have an agreed upon way of how your money is saved and spent, if you're pooling your earnings together. It's a top reason for divorces, so don't go in expecting things to work out perfectly.

You also seem a bit anxious about your worth relative to your wife, and fearful of abandonment if your perceived worth isn't enough for her. Talk to her about what she plans for in the future, what your relationship goals are, and find some reassurance. Don't bottle those thoughts up to boil over later.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2526016
Old Retiredfag reporting in.

I semi retired in 2018 and my wife just gave her notice recently. We took turns being the higher earner for most of our careers but in the last 7-8 years her annual salary + bonus was far more than I ever made in a single year. Easily more than 2x.

We were careful with our money over the years and are retiring with no debt at least 10 years before most working stiffs do.

The biggest "secret" to that is we paid ourselves first before spending the fun money. We made a list of our priorities and made sure most of the money went towards that: maxing 401ks, contributing to 529 college funds, paying down the mortgage etc... We determined who would pay for what and that's how the bills got paid. Short term savings in a joint account, but all remaining "fun money" went to separate checking accounts. That way we each spent on stuff we wanted without pissing the other person off. No arguing over spending in 25 years.

Don't base your worth on your job and how much you make. It's a fool's errand. As long as you make enough to live on and have the right partner, you'll be happy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528678
$3k/month in child care is fucking insane. That's more than my wife and I's total expenses in an entire month.
The key is to have your living expenses not exceed in net income of the top earner. $2700 on a mortgage is quite high (that's a $600k+ home), even in expensive parts of the country. Having no payment on your cars will also help a TON.

Being able to live on a single income will then allow you or your wife to stay home with the kids until they go to school. Also, by having someone doing domestic stuff, your expenses will go down even further. The partner at home with the kid(s) will have the time to do lots of cooking, which saves a ton of money on groceries/fast food/eating out. Transportation expenses will go down, and they'll even be able to do things like home improvement or general repairs on stuff that you'd otherwise have to pay money for.

Also, if you're fortunate enough to have family nearby, the kids grandparents can help out with childcare. Most grandparents certainly wouldn't mind having their grandkids for a few hours, every 2 or 3 days.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You have two options here. I'm a professional mechanic and small gas engines are also something I do on the side.

Electric chain saws are shit. They just are. Unless you're prepared to be able to split that battery pack open when the cells don't hold any more power then forget it. Corded? Get real.

Chainsaws? Stihl. I've seen a Husqvarna weed Wacker burn out in a summer, one per year according to my roommate. I pulled it all apart, 30psi. compression. They need 90 on the spec sheet just to fire. Poulan, Craftsman, anything else, forget it. Stihl holds value and is one of the best saws out there. Just take care of it like you would a Lambo. You'll really be in for a good time then.

With regard to oil mixing, Walmart has bottles with all kinds of ratio measurements near the outdoor/sports section near the marine 2 cycle oil. May be some near the regular PMV oil as well. Take care now.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2530435
I’ve got a babby Ryobi. Tossed my crappy Poulan because I don’t use it enough to deal with gummy carbs and brittle primer bulbs and fuel lines every 2 years when I need to run the thing, and the Ryobi batteries work on other tools. I haven’t used the Ryobi a ton, but for what it has done, I had that whole damn bar deep in the base of some fat palm tree and it somehow kept running. It’s just some $100 model but it works better than I expected. If you went with one of the HP guys and a good battery pack, it’s likely going to run as good as any <$200 consumer gas saw.

Other options: look for a dead saw for cheap on Craigslist or FB marketplace, 50% chance it needs new fuel lines or a $20 carb and will run fine. Or check Walmart, I have been seeing a lot of yard equipment in the clearance aisle including these 2-stroke blowers and chainsaws from some company like Blackjack or Black Bear?? for <$100 and it was at multiple different stores.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2531754
He’s reciting second hand some myth from an old man who repairs small engines and has no idea what he’s talking about. Pretty sure alcohol burns cooler than gasoline, and ethanol is alcohol.

The reason people like to run 0% ethanol
like Rec 90 or overpriced TrueFuel is because ethanol degrades fairly quick and regular E10 gas will clog up those tiny carbs when you let it sit in there for weeks in between use. I’ve also heard it’s not good for some older style fuel lines, the rubber and plastic, but any engine made in the past few decades is designed to be run on gas with minimum 10% ethanol.

If you're in a camper, where does the toilet flush to? Is it a tank under your camper? Is it hooked up to a septic tank?

Also, a toilet gets new water from pipes and flushes into a drain. Is water source frozen or the drain frozen? If you have a septic, it's very unlikely the latter.

If the entire system is localized to your camper, go to Home Depot and buy an electric heat gun, preferably battery-operated. Then get on your hands and knees and modestly heat the waterworks. Do this every hour until weather improves. Don't overheat, you might loosen solder or gaskets. Just enough to warm things to a point that can melt ice, which needn't be very hot at all.

>but I figure there is some sort of thermocouple that senses when the pilot is lit, right? How do I trouble shoot this?
A lot of times they use a sense bulb if they don't have a thermocouple. Regardless, they can go bad and I've had to replace one before in a situation exactly like yours.

Trouble shooting--- are you sure there is enough gas pressure reaching the valve in the first place? If so, then suspect the sense bulb/thermocouple. If replacing it doesn't work, then you can replace the entire valve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Buy some thick plastic sheeting or tarps, enough to cover your greenhouse twice over, and buy some rolls of standard household fiberglass wall insulation, enough to cover the greenhouse once. Lay 1 layer of the plastic/tarp over the greenhouse, gluing the seams together. Then attach the fiberglass insulation to that layer of plastic with some spray adhesive. Then attach the second layer of plastic to the outside of the insulation with more spray adhesive. Glue the two sheets of plastic/tarp together around the edges. You now have a waterproof insulation blanket comprised of inexpensive materials you can buy at your local hardware store.

You can make it in sections if having it be 1 large blanket is too big to manage.

And if you want it to last, make sure whatever tarp or plastic sheeting you use is UV resistant.

I have had the LED light fixture on a ceiling fan fail due to a bad regulator inside the fan. It's one of the little boxes inside the housing where the fan direction and speed switches are. But that was an integrated light fixture, and didn't use bulbs. I just cut and spliced some wires to bypass it, and the light came back fine.

See if this is your problem: https://diy.stackexchange.com/questions/1511/what-is-the-purpose-of-a-watt-regulator-in-my-ceiling-fan

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533889
This guy is probably closest to the mark. For many years the EPA required energy star rating for ceiling fans and their lights. This required the use of watt limiters built into fans to restrict the power used by incandescent lamps.

Some of these watt limiters used the current of the load to provide enough voltage drop to power the device. CFL and LED lights don't draw linear loads, and thus the watt limiters behave like dimmers in that they interrupt the waveform and can damage LED lamps, especially the non dimmable types.

If not caused by watt limiters, they you may have a remote control unit in the fan. Many of these have thyristors controlling the light circuit, even if they don't dim. These will cause similar problems.

Everything that's been described as the problem is what I've experienced when CFL & LED lights are connected to incompatible control systems.

The OP may not know if there is an unused remote control system in the fan if it just has an on off wall control. Often a light switch that has not been replaced by a multi speed switch indicates there is a remote control on the fan.

You ruined those trees. You can't just cut the top part of a tree, especially a conifer. Next time get an arborist who knows what they're doing and not a landscaper. The trees will never look natural again. The wound where they were topped will never heal over. The open wound will collect water and quickly rot, then the rot will go down inside the tree. It won't heal over fast enough to compartmentalism the rot. In addition, the tree will now need a new leader branch to become the pseudo trunk. Once that pseudo trunk grows, the tree will have a trunk that is not straight at a joint that is rotted. It will be too dangerous (and ugly) to keep. Find trees that grow to the height you want. You can't keep a tree small that wants to be bigger. Take this as an opportunity to remove that terrible planter along with those poor poor juniper trees.

>>2528561
Those are both pretty basic reactions/procedures. I think I did both of those in my first year as well. Chemistry is a very complicated subject and lab techniques can get quite advanced. Typically chemistry courses have a theory and lab component that run simultaneously, so you apply whatever it is you are currently learning. Those two examples would be something done in an intro to organic chemistry course. Upper year courses you can deal with things like more advanced purification, air sensitive reactions (Schlenk line, glove box, etc), pyrophorics, many types of spectroscopy (UV VIS, NMR, IR, etc), chiral specificity, etc. There are a lot of branches to cover, though there is quite a bit of crossover between lab techniques

Caffeine extraction is a basic lab technique/concept (liquid liquid extraction based on solvency, and purification through recrystallization) and gets you using basic glassware (separatory funnel, flasks,maybe a rotovap, hotplate, scale). Nylon is a cool looking but simple demo showing polymerization. You literally just put two liquids in a beaker then pull some tongs through it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
you can ghettoize some things but there are others you will need, otherwise you can only get so far. You need ventilation, either by fume hood, backyard, etc. You need a hotplate to control precise temperatures for reactions as well as a means to accurate observe the temp. You need glassware, obviously. You need solvents, for organic/inorganic separations. You definitely need a digital scale (the more accurate the better, but you can get by with chink/aliexpress type pocket/food scales). You need utensils like stirrers, small powder spoons, etc. You need de-ionized water (distilled water in most stores). You definitely need graduated cylinders to measure fluid volumes.

you can get clever and get pretty far, but you can only get so far before you need very expensive machines to analyze the structure of and verify the identity of compounds.

>>2527930
>Honestly chemistry isn’t that dangerous
I mean...it's not, but the problem is that it can easily go into dangerous territory if you're not careful and if you don't know what you're doing.
>>2528560
>with regard to the dangers, is it not enough to just study well the exact synthesis i want to perform?
No, because if you only study that one synthesis, you don't know what other synthesis might be taking place if, due to lack of knowledge, or due to contaminants in the reactants, or due to some other imperfection, it goes sideways somewhere along the way. For example, you might, say, use the wrong vessel for performing the experiment, and have the reactant react with the vessel too. Or you might not be able to keep the reaction at the required temperature (maybe it's exothermic, and you poured too much, which sped up the reaction significantly, or some random contaminant acts as a catalyst, etc), and thus have it turn into something else while it's outside of the correct temperature range. What then?
Not to mention that things are never perfect. You will never only work with analytical grade reactants, perfectly clean glassware, perfectly linear heating and have perfectly fitted seals. There will always be a degree of uncertainty and imperfection which will eventually sway the reaction in a different direction. And if you don't have the theoretical base and the experience needed to anticipate the direction in which that reaction will be swayed, and therefore correct it before it happens, it can and will go very badly.

Yesterday anon tried to react baking soda with water to create a basic solution of sodium carbonate.

A Pyrex measuring cup was used to measure 150 ml distilled water. This was poured into a glass on the side. Next, 50grams of NaHCO3 was added to the glass Pyrex measuring cup. This was placed onto a heating element, and the 150ml water was added and heat was turned to maximum. The reaction began, and fizzing and bubbling was visible. As the heat increased, the solution began to boil. Anon stirred the solution with a wooden chopstick. After about 12 minutes, the glass measuring cup cracked. Anon panicked and assumed that all was lost.

Anon turned the heat down and took the cracked measuring cup off of the heating element. Anon had concerns that this glass cup would break, but he thought that Pyrex glass was designed to be heated, and he read that a metal container would not suffice for safety reasons.

When anon confirmed that the glass measuring cup had cracked but was not leaking, anon again placed it on the heating element at low heat. Anon continued stirring. The solution was supposed to become clear after about 30 minutes. Anon was patient but continued to turn the heat up again. After about 35 minutes, the solution had dehydrated and a thick mixture of wet sodium bicarbonate, or maybe some of it was sodium carbonate by now, remained. Anon was concerned because this was not at all what anon had read about.

Anon added more distilled water and cranked up the heat. After 10 more minutes, the solution was still very cloudy and not clear. The solution again dehydrated and a thick wet powder of sodium bicarbonate and maybe some sodium carbonate remained.

This was not the sodium carbonate clear liquid solution that anon had hoped to make. Anon's glass container was cracked. There was a huge mess. Anon's friend's wife was coming home soon. Anon put the solution into a plastic trash bag, along with the cracked Pyrex measuring cup.

>>2532844
Visit welding forums/read textbooks since you will need to see illustrations of how to splice beams. You can afford used steel in reasonable lengths so learn how to get that where ever you live. You don't need to splice a bunch of small sections if you find sources like dismantlers. Many can deliver to your site.

Practice welding and perform bend tests. What is not tested is not known. Destructive bend testing is easy and then you'll know you can produce proper joints.

>>2533520
is correct but don't guess on the dimensions or hardware size. There is plenty of info on beam splicing.

Also study bolted designs as they're easy to assemble (rent or buy a mag drill with some annular cutters). I have ample welding equipment but if the best way to make a connection isn't by welding then I don't weld it. Study how iron iron workers handle materials.

Do not make the noob error of lifting beams on forklift forks. Slings are much safer offering better control. If you pick a beam with forks place wood between the load and tines to reduce slippage.

Be methodical and copy success.

>>2529082
When you're in the hardware store picking up parts, definitely get a multimeter. It's a very useful device for a DIYer. If you're on a budget, Harbor Freight or the equivalent will have one cheap which should last you long enough.

I mentioned the voltage b/c the switch does a very simple thing. If the pressure in the tank falls below a set point, it closes the contacts you have circled in the original picture. Those contacts literally connect the black to black and white to white wires coming in and out of each conduit. One set comes from your breaker panel, and the other goes to your pump. That's it - contacts close, pump gets power, pump fills up pressure tank, contacts open, pump stops getting power.

if you measure the voltage coming from the panel (one black and one white) with your multimeter you'll get either ~120 or 240v. Most likely 240 unless you have some small pump.

you then want to check that the wires going to the pump are getting the same voltage when the contacts are closed.

Hope that makes sense - not trying to talk down to you, I'm just not sure how much of the basics you have down.

If you are getting the same voltage on both sets of wires, your pump is getting the right voltage, and unfortunately your pump may be busted (at that point, get a well/plumber guy to come out and do some more testing)

If you're getting zero voltage on the pump side, the switch is not connecting them. This is where i said do lightly sand/file the contacts down as sometimes they get fouled and won't close correctly. Hell, one time i had a silverfish get stuck in the contacts and i didn't have water for half a day due to a literal bug!

And if for some strange reason you have 240 coming out of the wall, but pump is getting less, switch is likely broken in another way and should be replaced.

Watch a few pump/switch/tank How To videos. They taught me a lot when i first moved to a house with a well.

>>2530445
OK, your readings are just showing that you have voltage coming into the switch from the supply, but it's not making it to the output. In other words, the switch isn't closing.
If there is no pressure in the system, then the switch contacts should be closed. Look at the switch's mechanism and see if you can find what's wrong.

Usually with these kinds of setups, if you want to find out if the switch is the problem or if it's further downstream, you can first check for voltage at the pressure switch input, then switch the breaker off and temporarily connect the switch's input and output wires using wirenuts (black to black, white to white, etc).... Switch the breaker back on and you have effectively hotwired your pump, which should cause it to start pumping.

Watch the first 3 minutes of this video, and this guy explains it pretty well.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AmUTNekC9EE

The type of pressure switch that you have is equipped with a reset lever. You have to hold that lever at the right position for a bit so that it will manually close the contacts in the switch, causing the pump to be energized and creating pressure in the system.... once it reaches a preset level, it will be able to sustain itself and you can release the lever.

The basic diagnostic flow with a "no water from my well pump" complaint is to make sure that the pump is receiving power. If it's getting power but it's not pumping, then suspect the pump, it's state of prime(in applicable pumps) or it's control box (for models equipped with a surface mounted control box)
You haven't really established yet whether or not it is properly receiving power.
